href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/community/blob/master/rfcs/20210930-enable-onednn-ops.md\"\u003eoneDNN CPU performance optimizations\u003c/a\u003e\nWindows x64 \u0026amp; x86.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWindows x64 \u0026amp; x86 packages:\u003c/strong\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eoneDNN optimizations are \u003cem\u003eenabled by default\u003c/em\u003e on X86 CPUs\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTo explicitly enable or disable oneDNN optimizations, set the environment variable \u003ccode\u003eTF_ENABLE_ONEDNN_OPTS\u003c/code\u003e to \u003ccode\u003e1\u003c/code\u003e (enable) or \u003ccode\u003e0\u003c/code\u003e (disable) before running TensorFlow. To fall back to default settings, unset the environment variable.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eoneDNN optimizations can yield slightly different numerical results compared to when oneDNN optimizations are disabled due to floating-point round-off errors from\ndifferent computation approaches and orders.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTo verify if oneDNN optimizations are on, look for a message with \u003cem\u003e\"oneDNN custom operations are on\"\u003c/em\u003e in the log. If the exact phrase is not there, it means they are off.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eMaking the \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e type system fully available:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.types.experimental.TraceType\u003c/code\u003e now allows custom tf.function inputs to declare Tensor decomposition and type casting support.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIntroducing \u003ccode\u003etf.types.experimental.FunctionType\u003c/code\u003e as the comprehensive representation of the signature of \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e callables. It can be accessed through the \u003ccode\u003efunction_type\u003c/code\u003e property of \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003es and \u003ccode\u003eConcreteFunction\u003c/code\u003es. See the \u003ccode\u003etf.types.experimental.FunctionType\u003c/code\u003e documentation for more details.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIntroducing \u003ccode\u003etf.types.experimental.AtomicFunction\u003c/code\u003e as the fastest way to perform TF computations in Python.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCan be accessed through \u003ccode\u003einference_fn\u003c/code\u003e property of \u003ccode\u003eConcreteFunction\u003c/code\u003es\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDoes not support gradients.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSee \u003ccode\u003etf.types.experimental.AtomicFunction\u003c/code\u003e documentation for how to call and use it.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMoved option \u003ccode\u003ewarm_start\u003c/code\u003e from \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.OptimizationOptions\u003c/code\u003e to \u003ccode\u003etf.data.Options\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.lite\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003esub_op\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003emul_op\u003c/code\u003e support broadcasting up to 6 dimensions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe \u003ccode\u003etflite::SignatureRunner\u003c/code\u003e class, which provides support for named parameters and for multiple named computations within a single TF Lite model, is no longer considered experimental. with TF 2.14. The TensorFlow 2.13.1 patch release will still have Python 3.8 support.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.Tensor\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe class hierarchy for \u003ccode\u003etf.Tensor\u003c/code\u003e has changed, and there are now explicit \u003ccode\u003eEagerTensor\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eSymbolicTensor\u003c/code\u003e classes for eager and tf.function respectively. Users who relied on the exact type of Tensor (e.g. \u003ccode\u003etype(t) == tf.Tensor\u003c/code\u003e) will need to update their code to use \u003ccode\u003eisinstance(t, tf.Tensor)\u003c/code\u003e. The \u003ccode\u003etf.is_symbolic_tensor\u003c/code\u003e helper added in 2.13 may be used when it is necessary to determine if a value is specifically a symbolic tensor.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v1.Session\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v1.Session.partial_run\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v1.Session.partial_run_setup\u003c/code\u003e will be deprecated in the next release.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-known-caveats-4\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" href=\"#known-caveats-4\"\u003eKnown Caveats\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.lite\u003c/code\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ewhen converter flag \"_experimenal_use_buffer_offset\" is enabled, additional metadata is automatically excluded from the generated model. The behaviour is the same as \"exclude_conversion_metadata\" is set\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIf the model is larger than 2GB, then we also require \"exclude_conversion_metadata\" flag to be set\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-major-features-and-improvements-4\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" href=\"#major-features-and-improvements-4\"\u003eMajor Features and Improvements\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe \u003ccode\u003etensorflow\u003c/code\u003e pip package has a new, optional installation method for Linux that installs necessary Nvidia CUDA libraries through pip. As long as the Nvidia driver is already installed on the system, you may now run \u003ccode\u003epip install tensorflow[and-cuda]\u003c/code\u003e to install TensorFlow's Nvidia CUDA library dependencies in the Python environment. Aside from the Nvidia driver, no other pre-existing Nvidia CUDA packages are necessary.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eEnable JIT-compiled i64-indexed kernels on GPU for large tensors with more than 2**32 elements.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUnary GPU kernels: Abs, Atanh, Acos, Acosh, Asin, Asinh, Atan, Cos, Cosh, Sin, Sinh, Tan, Tanh.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBinary GPU kernels: AddV2, Sub, Div, DivNoNan, Mul, MulNoNan, FloorDiv, Equal, NotEqual, Greater, GreaterEqual, LessEqual, Less.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.lite\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd experimental supports conversion of models that may be larger than 2GB before buffer deduplication\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.py_function\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003etf.numpy_function\u003c/code\u003e can now be used as function decorators for clearer code:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"@tf.py_function(Tout=tf.float32)\ndef my_fun(x):\n  print(\u0026quot;This always executes eagerly.\u0026quot;)\n  return x+1\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e@tf.py_function(Tout=tf.float32)\ndef my_fun(x):\n  print(\"This always executes eagerly.\")\n  return x+1\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.lite\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eStrided_Slice now supports \u003ccode\u003eUINT32\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.config.experimental.enable_tensor_float_32_execution\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDisabling TensorFloat-32 execution now causes TPUs to use float32 precision for float32 matmuls and other ops. TPUs have always used bfloat16 precision for certain ops, like matmul, when such ops had float32 inputs. Now, disabling TensorFloat-32 by calling \u003ccode\u003etf.config.experimental.enable_tensor_float_32_execution(False)\u003c/code\u003e will cause TPUs to use float32 precision for such ops instead of bfloat16.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.experimental.dtensor\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAPI changes for Relayout. Added a new API, \u003ccode\u003edtensor.relayout_like\u003c/code\u003e, for relayouting a tensor according to the layout of another tensor.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003edtensor.get_default_mesh\u003c/code\u003e, for retrieving the current default mesh under the dtensor context.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e*fft* ops now support dtensors with any layout. Fixed bug in 'fft2d/fft3d', 'ifft2d/ifft3d', 'rfft2d/rfft3d', and 'irfft2d/irfft3d' for sharde input. Refer to this \u003ca href=\"https://blog.tensorflow.org/2023/08/distributed-fast-fourier-transform-in-tensorflow.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eblog post\u003c/a\u003e for details.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.experimental.strict_mode\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded a new API, \u003ccode\u003estrict_mode\u003c/code\u003e, which converts all deprecation warnings into runtime errors with instructions on switching to a recommended  substitute.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTensorFlow Debugger (tfdbg) CLI: ncurses-based CLI for tfdbg v1 was removed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTensorFlow now supports C++ RTTI on mobile and Android. To enable this feature, pass the flag \u003ccode\u003e--define=tf_force_rtti=true\u003c/code\u003e to Bazel when building TensorFlow. This may be needed when linking TensorFlow into RTTI-enabled programs since mixing RTTI and non-RTTI code can cause ABI issues.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.ones\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003etf.zeros\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003etf.fill\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003etf.ones_like\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003etf.zeros_like\u003c/code\u003e now take an additional Layout argument that controls the output layout of their results.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.nest\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e now support user defined classes implementing \u003ccode\u003e__tf_flatten__\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003e__tf_unflatten__\u003c/code\u003e methods. See \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/04869b4e63bfc03cb13627b3e1b879fdd0f69e34/tensorflow/python/util/nest_util.py#L97\"\u003enest_util code examples\u003c/a\u003e\nfor an example.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTensorFlow IO support is now available for Apple Silicon packages.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eRefactor CpuExecutable to propagate LLVM errors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-keras-2\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" href=\"#keras-2\"\u003eKeras\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eKeras is a framework built on top of the TensorFlow. dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.lite\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded 16-bit and 64-bit float type support for built-in op \u003ccode\u003ecast\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe Python TF Lite Interpreter bindings now have an option \u003ccode\u003eexperimental_disable_delegate_clustering\u003c/code\u003e to turn-off delegate clustering.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded int16x8 support for the built-in op \u003ccode\u003eexp\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded int16x8 support for the built-in op \u003ccode\u003emirror_pad\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded int16x8 support for the built-in ops \u003ccode\u003espace_to_batch_nd\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003ebatch_to_space_nd\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded 16-bit int type support for built-in op \u003ccode\u003eless\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003egreater_than\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eequal\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded 8-bit and 16-bit support for \u003ccode\u003efloor_div\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003efloor_mod\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded 16-bit and 32-bit int support for the built-in op \u003ccode\u003ebitcast\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded 8-bit/16-bit/32-bit int/uint support for the built-in op \u003ccode\u003ebitwise_xor\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded int16 indices support for built-in op \u003ccode\u003egather\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003egather_nd\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded 8-bit/16-bit/32-bit int/uint support for the built-in op \u003ccode\u003eright_shift\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded reference implementation for 16-bit int unquantized \u003ccode\u003eadd\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded reference implementation for 16-bit int and 32-bit unsigned int unquantized \u003ccode\u003emul\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eadd_op\u003c/code\u003e supports broadcasting up to 6 dimensions.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded 16-bit support for \u003ccode\u003etop_k\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eConcreteFunction (\u003ccode\u003etf.types.experimental.ConcreteFunction\u003c/code\u003e) as generated through \u003ccode\u003eget_concrete_function\u003c/code\u003e now performs holistic input validation similar to calling \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e directly. This can cause breakages where existing calls pass Tensors with the wrong shape or omit certain non-Tensor arguments (including default values).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.nn\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.nn.embedding_lookup_sparse\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003etf.nn.safe_embedding_lookup_sparse\u003c/code\u003e now support ids and weights described by \u003ccode\u003etf.RaggedTensor\u003c/code\u003es.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded a new boolean argument \u003ccode\u003eallow_fast_lookup\u003c/code\u003e to \u003ccode\u003etf.nn.embedding_lookup_sparse\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003etf.nn.safe_embedding_lookup_sparse\u003c/code\u003e, which enables a simplified and typically faster lookup procedure.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.zip\u003c/code\u003e now supports Python-style zipping, i.e. \u003ccode\u003eDataset.zip(a, b, c)\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.shuffle\u003c/code\u003e now supports \u003ccode\u003etf.data.UNKNOWN_CARDINALITY\u003c/code\u003e When doing a \"full shuffle\" using  \u003ccode\u003edataset = dataset.shuffle(dataset.cardinality())\u003c/code\u003e. But remember, a \"full shuffle\" will load the full dataset into memory so that it can be shuffled, so make sure to only use this with small datasets or datasets of small objects (like filenames).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.math\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.nn.top_k\u003c/code\u003e now supports specifying the output index type via parameter \u003ccode\u003eindex_type\u003c/code\u003e.  Supported types are \u003ccode\u003etf.int16\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003etf.int32\u003c/code\u003e (default), and \u003ccode\u003etf.int64\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.SavedModel\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIntroduced class method \u003ccode\u003etf.saved_model.experimental.Fingerprint.from_proto(proto)\u003c/code\u003e, which can be used to construct a \u003ccode\u003eFingerprint\u003c/code\u003e object directly from a protobuf.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIntroduced member method \u003ccode\u003etf.saved_model.experimental.Fingerprint.singleprint()\u003c/code\u003e, which provides a convenient way to uniquely identify a SavedModel.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-bug-fixes-and-other-changes-5\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.Variable\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eChanged resource variables to inherit from \u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v2.Variable\u003c/code\u003e instead of \u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v1.Variable\u003c/code\u003e. Some checks for \u003ccode\u003eisinstance(v, tf compat.v1.Variable)\u003c/code\u003e that previously returned True may now return False.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOpened an experimental API, \u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.experimental.coordinator.get_current_worker_index\u003c/code\u003e, for retrieving the worker index from within a worker, when using parameter server training with a custom training loop.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.experimental.dtensor\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDeprecated \u003ccode\u003edtensor.run_on\u003c/code\u003e in favor of \u003ccode\u003edtensor.default_mesh\u003c/code\u003e to correctly indicate that the context does not override the mesh that the ops and functions will run on, it only sets a fallback default mesh.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eList of members of \u003ccode\u003edtensor.Layout\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003edtensor.Mesh\u003c/code\u003e have slightly changed as part of efforts to consolidate the C++ and Python source code with pybind11. Most notably, \u003ccode\u003edtensor.Layout.serialized_string\u003c/code\u003e is removed.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMinor API changes to represent Single Device Layout for non-distributed Tensors inside DTensor functions. Runtime support will be added soon.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.experimental.ExtensionType\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.experimental.ExtensionType\u003c/code\u003e now supports Python \u003ccode\u003etuple\u003c/code\u003e as the type annotation of its fields.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.nest\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDeprecated API \u003ccode\u003etf.nest.is_sequence\u003c/code\u003e has now been deleted. Please use \u003ccode\u003etf.nest.is_nested\u003c/code\u003e instead.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-keras-3\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" href=\"#keras-3\"\u003eKeras\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eKeras is a framework built on top of the TensorFlow. See more details on the \u003ca href=\"https://keras.io/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eKeras website\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-breaking-changes-6\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" href=\"#breaking-changes-6\"\u003eBreaking Changes\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRemoved the Keras scikit-learn API wrappers (\u003ccode\u003eKerasClassifier\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eKerasRegressor\u003c/code\u003e), which had been deprecated in August 2021. We recommend using \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/adriangb/scikeras\"\u003eSciKeras\u003c/a\u003e instead.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe default Keras model saving format is now the Keras v3 format: calling \u003ccode\u003emodel.save(\"xyz.keras\")\u003c/code\u003e will no longer create a H5 file, it will create a native Keras model file. This will only be breaking for you if you were manually inspecting or modifying H5 files saved by Keras under a \u003ccode\u003e.keras\u003c/code\u003e extension. If this breaks you, simply add \u003ccode\u003esave_format=\"h5\"\u003c/code\u003e to your \u003ccode\u003e.save()\u003c/code\u003e call to revert back to the prior behavior.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003ekeras.utils.TimedThread\u003c/code\u003e utility to run a timed thread every x seconds. It can be used to run a threaded function alongside model training or any other snippet of code.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIn the \u003ccode\u003ekeras\u003c/code\u003e PyPI package, accessible symbols are now restricted to symbols that are intended to be public. This may affect your code if you were using \u003ccode\u003eimport keras\u003c/code\u003e and you used \u003ccode\u003ekeras\u003c/code\u003e functions that were not public APIs, but were accessible in earlier versions with direct imports. In those cases, please use the following guideline:\n-  The API may be available in the public Keras API under a different name, so make sure to look for it on keras.io or TensorFlow docs and switch to the public version.\n-  It could also be a simple python or TF utility that you could easily copy over to your own codebase. In those case, just make it your own!\n-  If you believe it should definitely be a public Keras API, please open a feature request in keras GitHub repo.\n-  As a workaround, you could import the same private symbol keras \u003ccode\u003ekeras.src\u003c/code\u003e, but keep in mind the \u003ccode\u003esrc\u003c/code\u003e namespace is not stable and those APIs may change or be removed in the future.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-major-features-and-improvements-7\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" href=\"#major-features-and-improvements-7\"\u003eMajor Features and Improvements\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded F-Score metrics \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.metrics.FBetaScore\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.metrics.F1Score\u003c/code\u003e, and \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.metrics.R2Score\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded activation function \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.activations.mish\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded experimental \u003ccode\u003ekeras.metrics.experimental.PyMetric\u003c/code\u003e API for metrics that run Python code on the host CPU (compiled outside of the TensorFlow graph). This can be used for integrating metrics from external Python libraries (like sklearn or pycocotools) into Keras as first-class Keras metrics.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.Lion\u003c/code\u003e optimizer.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.layers.SpectralNormalization\u003c/code\u003e layer wrapper to perform spectral normalization on the weights of a target layer.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe \u003ccode\u003eSidecarEvaluatorModelExport\u003c/code\u003e callback has been added to Keras as \u003ccode\u003ekeras.callbacks.SidecarEvaluatorModelExport\u003c/code\u003e. This callback allows for exporting the model the best-scoring model as evaluated by a \u003ccode\u003eSidecarEvaluator\u003c/code\u003e evaluator. The evaluator regularly evaluates the model and exports it if the user-defined comparison function determines that it is an improvement.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded warmup capabilities to \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.schedules.CosineDecay\u003c/code\u003e learning rate scheduler. You can now specify an initial and target learning rate, and our scheduler will perform a linear interpolation between the two after which it will begin a decay phase.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded experimental support for an exactly-once visitation guarantee for evaluating Keras models trained with \u003ccode\u003etf.distribute ParameterServerStrategy\u003c/code\u003e, via the \u003ccode\u003eexact_evaluation_shards\u003c/code\u003e argument in \u003ccode\u003eModel.fit\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eModel.evaluate\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.__internal__.KerasTensor\u003c/code\u003e,\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.__internal__.SparseKerasTensor\u003c/code\u003e, and \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.__internal__.RaggedKerasTensor\u003c/code\u003e classes. You can use these classes to do instance type checking and type annotations for layer/model inputs and outputs.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAll the \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.dtensor.experimental.optimizers\u003c/code\u003e classes have been merged with \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers\u003c/code\u003e. You can migrate your code to use \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers\u003c/code\u003e directly. The API namespace for \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.dtensor.experimental.optimizers\u003c/code\u003e will be removed in future releases.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded support for \u003ccode\u003eclass_weight\u003c/code\u003e for 3+ dimensional targets (e.g. image segmentation masks) in \u003ccode\u003eModel.fit\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded a new loss, \u003ccode\u003ekeras.losses.CategoricalFocalCrossentropy\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRemove the \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.dtensor.experimental.layout_map_scope()\u003c/code\u003e. You can user the \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.dtensor.experimental.LayoutMap.scope()\u003c/code\u003e instead.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-security\" Packaging\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRemoved redundant packages \u003ccode\u003etensorflow-gpu\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003etf-nightly-gpu\u003c/code\u003e. These packages were removed and replaced with packages that direct users to switch to \u003ccode\u003etensorflow\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003etf-nightly\u003c/code\u003e respectively. Since TensorFlow 2.1, the only difference between these two sets of packages was their names, so there is no loss of functionality or GPU support. See \u003ca href=\"https://pypi.org/project/tensorflow-gpu\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ehttps://pypi.org/project/tensorflow-gpu\u003c/a\u003e for more details.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e now uses the Python inspect library directly for parsing the signature of the Python function it is decorated on. This change may break code where the function signature is malformed, but was ignored previously, such as:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUsing \u003ccode\u003efunctools.wraps\u003c/code\u003e on a function with different signature\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUsing \u003ccode\u003efunctools.partial\u003c/code\u003e with an invalid \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e input\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e now enforces input parameter names to be valid Python identifiers. Incompatible names are automatically sanitized similarly to existing SavedModel signature behavior.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eParameterless \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003es are assumed to have an empty \u003ccode\u003einput_signature\u003c/code\u003e instead of an undefined one even if the \u003ccode\u003einput_signature\u003c/code\u003e is unspecified.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.types.experimental.TraceType\u003c/code\u003e now requires an additional \u003ccode\u003eplaceholder_value\u003c/code\u003e method to be defined.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e now traces with placeholder values generated by TraceType instead of the value itself.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eExperimental APIs \u003ccode\u003etf.config.experimental.enable_mlir_graph_optimization\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003etf.config.experimental.disable_mlir_graph_optimization\u003c/code\u003e were removed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-major-features-and-improvements-8\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" added.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSupport for Python 3.7 has been removed. We are not releasing any more patches for Python 3.7.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.lite\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd 16-bit float type support for built-in op \u003ccode\u003efill\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTranspose now supports 6D tensors.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFloat LSTM now supports diagonal recurrent tensors: \u003ca href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.08023\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ehttps://arxiv.org/abs/1903.08023\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.experimental.dtensor\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCoordination service now works with \u003ccode\u003edtensor.initialize_accelerator_system\u003c/code\u003e, and enabled by default.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd \u003ccode\u003etf.experimental.dtensor.is_dtensor\u003c/code\u003e to check if a tensor is a DTensor instance.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded support for alternative checkpointing protocol which makes it possible to checkpoint the state of the input pipeline without having to store the contents of internal buffers. The new functionality can be enabled through the \u003ccode\u003eexperimental_symbolic_checkpoint\u003c/code\u003e option of \u003ccode\u003etf.data.Options()\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded a new \u003ccode\u003ererandomize_each_iteration\u003c/code\u003e argument for the \u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.random()\u003c/code\u003e operation, which controls whether the sequence of generated random numbers should be re-randomized every epoch or not (the default behavior). If \u003ccode\u003eseed\u003c/code\u003e is set and \u003ccode\u003ererandomize_each_iteration=True\u003c/code\u003e, the \u003ccode\u003erandom()\u003c/code\u003e operation will produce a different (deterministic) sequence of numbers every epoch.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded a new \u003ccode\u003ererandomize_each_iteration\u003c/code\u003e argument for the \u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.sample_from_datasets()\u003c/code\u003e operation, which controls whether the sequence of generated random numbers used for sampling should be re-randomized every epoch or not. If \u003ccode\u003eseed\u003c/code\u003e is set and \u003ccode\u003ererandomize_each_iteration=True\u003c/code\u003e, the \u003ccode\u003esample_from_datasets()\u003c/code\u003e operation will use a different (deterministic) sequence of numbers every epoch.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.test\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etf.test.experimental.sync_devices\u003c/code\u003e, which is useful for accurately measuring performance in benchmarks.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.experimental.dtensor\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded experimental support to ReduceScatter fuse on GPU See more details on the Keras \u003ca href=\"https://keras.io/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ewebsite\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-breaking-changes-8\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" href=\"#breaking-changes-8\"\u003eBreaking Changes\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMoved all saving-related utilities to a new namespace, \u003ccode\u003ekeras.saving\u003c/code\u003e, for example: \u003ccode\u003ekeras.saving.load_model\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003ekeras.saving.save_model\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003ekeras.saving.custom_object_scope\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003ekeras.saving.get_custom_objects\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003ekeras.saving.register_keras_serializable\u003c/code\u003e,\u003ccode\u003ekeras.saving.get_registered_name\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003ekeras.saving.get_registered_object\u003c/code\u003e. The previous API locations (in \u003ccode\u003ekeras.utils\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003ekeras.models\u003c/code\u003e) will be available indefinitely, but we recommend you update your code to point to the new API locations.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eImprovements and fixes in Keras loss masking:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhether you represent a ragged tensor as a \u003ccode\u003etf.RaggedTensor\u003c/code\u003e or using \u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/guide/keras/masking_and_padding\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ekeras masking\u003c/a\u003e, the returned loss values should be the identical to each other. In previous versions Keras may have silently ignored the mask.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIf you use masked losses with Keras the loss values may be different in TensorFlow \u003ccode\u003e2.12\u003c/code\u003e compared to previous versions.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIn cases where the mask was previously ignored, you will now get an error if you pass a mask with an incompatible shape.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-major-features-and-improvements-9\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" href=\"#major-features-and-improvements-9\"\u003eMajor Features and Improvements\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe new Keras model saving format (\u003ccode\u003e.keras\u003c/code\u003e) is available. You can start using it via \u003ccode\u003emodel.save(f\"{fname}.keras\", save_format=\"keras_v3\")\u003c/code\u003e. In the future it will become the default for all files with the \u003ccode\u003e.keras\u003c/code\u003e extension. This file format targets the Python runtime only and makes it possible to reload Python objects identical to the saved originals. The format supports non-numerical state such as vocabulary files and lookup tables, and it is easy to customize in the case of custom layers with exotic elements of state (e.g. a FIFOQueue). The format does not rely on bytecode or pickling, and is safe by default. Note that as a result, Python \u003ccode\u003elambdas\u003c/code\u003e are disallowed at loading time. If you want to use \u003ccode\u003elambdas\u003c/code\u003e, you can pass \u003ccode\u003esafe_mode=False\u003c/code\u003e to the loading method (only do this if you trust the source of the model).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded a \u003ccode\u003emodel.export(filepath)\u003c/code\u003e API to create a lightweight SavedModel artifact that can be used for inference (e.g. with TF-Serving).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003ekeras.export.ExportArchive\u003c/code\u003e class for low-level customization of the process of exporting SavedModel artifacts for inference. Both ways of exporting models are based on \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e tracing and produce a TF program composed of TF ops. They are meant primarily for environments where the TF runtime is available, but not the Python interpreter, as is typical for production with TF Serving.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded utility \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.utils.FeatureSpace\u003c/code\u003e, a one-stop shop for structured data preprocessing and encoding.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etf.SparseTensor\u003c/code\u003e input support to \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.layers.Embedding\u003c/code\u003e layer. The layer now accepts a new boolean argument \u003ccode\u003esparse\u003c/code\u003e. If \u003ccode\u003esparse\u003c/code\u003e is set to True, the layer returns a SparseTensor instead of a dense Tensor. Defaults to False.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003ejit_compile\u003c/code\u003e as a settable property to \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.Model\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003esynchronized\u003c/code\u003e optional parameter to \u003ccode\u003elayers.BatchNormalization\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded deprecation warning to \u003ccode\u003elayers.experimental.SyncBatchNormalization\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.layers.BatchNormalization\u003c/code\u003e to support masking of the inputs (\u003ccode\u003emask\u003c/code\u003e argument) when computing the mean and \u003ccode\u003eshow_trainable\u003c/code\u003e option to \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.utils.model_to_dot\u003c/code\u003e to display layer trainable status in model plots.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd ability to save a \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.utils.FeatureSpace\u003c/code\u003e object, via dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.Optimizer\u003c/code\u003e now points to the new Keras optimizer, and\nold optimizers have moved to the \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.legacy\u003c/code\u003e namespace.\nIf you find your workflow failing due to this change,\nyou may be facing one of the following issues:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCheckpoint loading failure.\u003c/strong\u003e The new optimizer handles optimizer\nstate differently from the old optimizer, which simplies the logic of\ncheckpoint saving/loading, but at the cost of breaking checkpoint\nbackward compatibility in some cases. If you want to keep using an old\ncheckpoint, please change your optimizer to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.legacy.XXX\u003c/code\u003e (e.g.\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.legacy.Adam\u003c/code\u003e).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTF1 compatibility.\u003c/strong\u003e The new optimizer does not support TF1 any more,\nso please use the legacy optimizer \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizer.legacy.XXX\u003c/code\u003e.\nWe highly recommend to migrate your workflow to TF2 for stable\nsupport and new features.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAPI not found.\u003c/strong\u003e The new optimizer has a different set of public APIs\nfrom the old optimizer. These API changes are mostly related to\ngetting rid of slot variables and TF1 support. Please check the API\ndocumentation to find alternatives to the missing API. If you must\ncall the deprecated API, please change your optimizer to the legacy\noptimizer.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLearning rate schedule access.\u003c/strong\u003e When using a \u003ccode\u003eLearningRateSchedule\u003c/code\u003e,\nThe new optimizer's \u003ccode\u003elearning_rate\u003c/code\u003e property returns the\ncurrent learning rate value instead of a \u003ccode\u003eLearningRateSchedule\u003c/code\u003e object\nas before. If you need to access the \u003ccode\u003eLearningRateSchedule\u003c/code\u003e object,\nplease use \u003ccode\u003eoptimizer._learning_rate\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eYou implemented a custom optimizer based on the old optimizer.\u003c/strong\u003e\nPlease set your optimizer to subclass\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizer.legacy.XXX\u003c/code\u003e. If you want to migrate to the new\noptimizer and find it does not support your optimizer, please file\nan issue in the Keras GitHub repo.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eError such as \u003ccode\u003eCannot recognize variable...\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/strong\u003e The new optimizer\nrequires all optimizer variables to be created at the first\n\u003ccode\u003eapply_gradients()\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003eminimize()\u003c/code\u003e call. If your workflow calls\noptimizer to update different parts of model in multiple stages,\nplease call \u003ccode\u003eoptimizer.build(model.trainable_variables)\u003c/code\u003e before the\ntraining loop.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePerformance regression on \u003ccode\u003eParameterServerStrategy\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/strong\u003e This could be\nsignificant if you have many PS servers. We are aware of this issue and\nworking on fixes, for now we suggest using the legacy optimizers when\nusing \u003ccode\u003eParameterServerStrategy\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTimeout or performance loss.\u003c/strong\u003e We don't anticipate this to happen, but\nif you see such issues, please use the legacy optimizer, and file\nan issue in the Keras GitHub repo.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe old Keras optimizer will never be deleted, but will not see any\nnew feature additions.\nNew optimizers (e.g., \u003ccode\u003eAdafactor\u003c/code\u003e) will\nonly be implemented based on \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.Optimizer\u003c/code\u003e, the new\nbase class.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eReturns the current metrics values of the model as a dict.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded group normalization layer optimizer \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.Adafactor\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003ewarmstart_embedding_matrix\u003c/code\u003e to which may include previously unseen words (the embedding\nvectors for unseen words will be randomly initialized).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.Variable\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003eCompositeTensor\u003c/code\u003e as a baseclass to \u003ccode\u003eResourceVariable\u003c/code\u003e. This\nallows \u003ccode\u003etf.Variable\u003c/code\u003es to be nested in \u003ccode\u003etf.experimental.ExtensionType\u003c/code\u003es.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded a new constructor argument \u003ccode\u003eexperimental_enable_variable_lifting\u003c/code\u003e\nto \u003ccode\u003etf.Variable\u003c/code\u003e, defaulting to True. When it's \u003ccode\u003eFalse\u003c/code\u003e, the variable\nwon't be lifted out of \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e, thus it can be used as a\n\u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e-local variable: during each execution of the\n\u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e, the variable will be created and then disposed, similar\nto a local (i.e. stack-allocated) variable in C/C++. Currently\n\u003ccode\u003eexperimental_enable_variable_lifting=False\u003c/code\u003e only works on non-XLA\ndevices (e.g. under \u003ccode\u003e@tf.function(jit_compile=False)\u003c/code\u003e).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTF SavedModel:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003efingerprint.pb\u003c/code\u003e to the SavedModel directory. and\n\u003ccode\u003ekeras.layers.AdditiveAttention\u003c/code\u003e is now specified in the \u003ccode\u003ecall()\u003c/code\u003e method via\nthe \u003ccode\u003euse_causal_mask\u003c/code\u003e argument (rather than in the constructor), for\nconsistency with other layers.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSome files in \u003ccode\u003etensorflow/python/training\u003c/code\u003e have been moved to\n\u003ccode\u003etensorflow/python/tracking\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003etensorflow/python/checkpoint\u003c/code\u003e. Please\nupdate your imports accordingly, the old files will be removed in Release\n2.11.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.experimental.Optimizer\u003c/code\u003e will graduate in Release 2.11,\nwhich means \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.Optimizer\u003c/code\u003e will be an alias of\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.experimental.Optimizer\u003c/code\u003e. The current\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.Optimizer\u003c/code\u003e will continue to be supported as\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.legacy.Optimizer\u003c/code\u003e,\ne.g.,\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.legacy.Adam\u003c/code\u003e. Most users won't be affected by this\nchange, but please check the\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/keras/optimizers/experimental\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eAPI doc\u003c/a\u003e\nif any API used in your workflow is changed or deprecated, and make\nadaptations. If you decide to keep using the old optimizer, please\nexplicitly change your optimizer to \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.legacy.Optimizer\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRNG behavior change for \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.initializers\u003c/code\u003e. Keras initializers will now\nuse stateless random ops to generate random numbers.\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBoth seeded and unseeded initializers will always generate the same\nvalues every time they are called (for a given variable shape). For\nunseeded initializers (\u003ccode\u003eseed=None\u003c/code\u003e), a random seed will be created and\nassigned at initializer creation (different initializer instances get\ndifferent seeds).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAn unseeded initializer will raise a warning if it is reused (called)\nmultiple times. This is because it would produce the same values each\ntime, which may not be intended.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAPI changes under \u003ccode\u003etf.experimental.dtensor\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNew API for initialization of CPU/GPU/TPU in dtensor.\n\u003ccode\u003edtensor.initialize_accelerator_system\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003edtensor.shutdown_accelerator_system\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe following existing API will be removed:\n\u003ccode\u003edtensor.initialize_multi_client\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003edtensor.initialize_tpu_system\u003c/code\u003e, and\n\u003ccode\u003edtensor.shutdown_tpu_system\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-deprecations\" Accessing\n\u003ccode\u003etensorflow::error::Code\u003c/code\u003e fields is fine.\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUse the constructors such as as\n\u003ccode\u003etensorflow::errors::IsInvalidArgument\u003c/code\u003e if needed.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIn the last resort, dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.lite\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNew operations supported:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003etflite SelectV2 now supports 5D.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.einsum\u003c/code\u003e is supported with multiple unknown shapes.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.unsortedsegmentprod\u003c/code\u003e op is supported.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.unsortedsegmentmax\u003c/code\u003e op is supported.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.unsortedsegmentsum\u003c/code\u003e op is supported.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUpdates to existing operations:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etfl.scatter_nd\u003c/code\u003e now supports I1 for the \u003ccode\u003eupdate\u003c/code\u003e arg.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUpgrade Flatbuffers v2.0.5 from v1.12.0\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eEinsumDense\u003c/code\u003e layer is moved from experimental to core. Its import path\nis moved from \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.layers.experimental.EinsumDense\u003c/code\u003e to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.layers.EinsumDense\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.utils.audio_dataset_from_directory\u003c/code\u003e utility to easily\ngenerate audio classification datasets from directories of \u003ccode\u003e.wav\u003c/code\u003e files.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003esubset=\"both\"\u003c/code\u003e support in\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.utils.image_dataset_from_directory\u003c/code\u003e,\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.utils.text_dataset_from_directory\u003c/code\u003e,\nand \u003ccode\u003eaudio_dataset_from_directory\u003c/code\u003e, to be used with the\n\u003ccode\u003evalidation_split\u003c/code\u003e argument, for returning both dataset splits at once,\nas a tuple.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.utils.split_dataset\u003c/code\u003e utility to split a \u003ccode\u003eDataset\u003c/code\u003e object\nor a list/tuple of arrays into two \u003ccode\u003eDataset\u003c/code\u003e objects (e.g. train/test).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded step granularity to \u003ccode\u003eBackupAndRestore\u003c/code\u003e callback for handling\ndistributed training failures \u0026amp; restarts. The training state can now be\nrestored at the exact epoch and step at which it was previously saved\nbefore failing.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/keras/dtensor/experimental/optimizers/AdamW\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.dtensor.experimental.optimizers.AdamW\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e.\nThis optimizer is similar to the existing\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/keras/optimizers/experimental/AdamW\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003ekeras.optimizers.experimental.AdamW\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e,\nand works in the DTensor training use case.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eImproved masking support for\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/keras/layers/MultiHeadAttention\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.layers.MultiHeadAttention\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e.\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eImplicit masks for \u003ccode\u003equery\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003ekey\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003evalue\u003c/code\u003e inputs will\nautomatically be used to compute a correct attention mask for the\nlayer. These padding masks will be combined with any\n\u003ccode\u003eattention_mask\u003c/code\u003e passed in directly when calling the layer. This can\nbe used with\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/keras/layers/Embedding\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.layers.Embedding\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\nwith \u003ccode\u003emask_zero=True\u003c/code\u003e to automatically infer a correct padding mask.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded a \u003ccode\u003euse_causal_mask\u003c/code\u003e call time argument to the layer. Passing\n\u003ccode\u003euse_causal_mask=True\u003c/code\u003e will compute a causal attention mask, and\noptionally combine it with any \u003ccode\u003eattention_mask\u003c/code\u003e passed in directly\nwhen calling the layer.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003eignore_class\u003c/code\u003e argument in the loss\n\u003ccode\u003eSparseCategoricalCrossentropy\u003c/code\u003e and metrics \u003ccode\u003eIoU\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eMeanIoU\u003c/code\u003e, to\nspecify a class index to be ignored during loss/metric computation (e.g.\na background/void class).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/keras/models/experimental/SharpnessAwareMinimization\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.models.experimental.SharpnessAwareMinimization\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e.\nThis class implements the sharpness-aware minimization technique, which\nboosts model performance on various tasks, e.g., ResNet on image\nclassification.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded support for cross-trainer data caching in tf.data service. This\nsaves computation resources when concurrent training jobs train from the\nsame dataset. See\n(\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/data/experimental/service#sharing_tfdata_service_with_concurrent_trainers\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ehttps://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/data/experimental/service#sharing_tfdata_service_with_concurrent_trainers\u003c/a\u003e)\nfor more details.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003edataset_id\u003c/code\u003e to \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.service.register_dataset\u003c/code\u003e.\nIf provided, \u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e service will use the provided ID for the dataset.\nIf the dataset ID already exists, no new dataset will be registered.\nThis is useful if multiple training jobs need to use the same dataset\nfor training. In this case, users should call \u003ccode\u003eregister_dataset\u003c/code\u003e with\nthe same \u003ccode\u003edataset_id\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded a new field, \u003ccode\u003einject_prefetch\u003c/code\u003e, to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.OptimizationOptions\u003c/code\u003e. If it is set to\n\u003ccode\u003eTrue\u003c/code\u003e,\u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e will now automatically add a \u003ccode\u003eprefetch\u003c/code\u003e transformation\nto datasets that end in synchronous transformations. This enables data\ngeneration to be overlapped with data consumption. This may cause a\nsmall increase in memory usage due to buffering. To enable this\nbehavior, set \u003ccode\u003einject_prefetch=True\u003c/code\u003e in\n\u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.OptimizationOptions\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded a new value to \u003ccode\u003etf.data.Options.autotune.autotune_algorithm\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003ccode\u003eSTAGE_BASED\u003c/code\u003e. If the autotune algorithm is set to \u003ccode\u003eSTAGE_BASED\u003c/code\u003e, then\nit runs a new algorithm that can get the same performance with lower\nCPU/memory usage.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/data/experimental/from_list\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.from_list\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e,\na new API for creating \u003ccode\u003eDataset\u003c/code\u003es from lists of elements.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGraduated experimental APIs:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/data/Dataset/#counter\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.counter\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e,\nwhich creates \u003ccode\u003eDataset\u003c/code\u003es of indefinite sequences of numbers.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/data/Dataset/#ignore_errors\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.ignore_errors\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e,\nwhich drops erroneous elements from \u003ccode\u003eDataset\u003c/code\u003es.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/data/Dataset#rebatch\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.rebatch\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e,\na new API for rebatching the elements of a dataset.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/distribute/experimental/PreemptionCheckpointHandler\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.experimental.PreemptionCheckpointHandler\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\nto handle worker preemption/maintenance and cluster-wise consistent\nerror reporting for \u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.MultiWorkerMirroredStrategy\u003c/code\u003e.\nSpecifically, for the type of interruption with advance notice, it\nautomatically saves a checkpoint, exits the program without raising an\nunrecoverable error, and restores the progress when training restarts.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.math\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etf.math.approx_max_k\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003etf.math.approx_min_k\u003c/code\u003e which are the\noptimized alternatives to \u003ccode\u003etf.math.top_k\u003c/code\u003e on TPU. The performance\ndifference ranges from 8 to 100 times depending on the size of k. When\nrunning on CPU and GPU, a non-optimized XLA kernel is used.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.train\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etf.train.TrackableView\u003c/code\u003e which allows users to inspect the\nTensorFlow Trackable object (e.g. \u003ccode\u003etf.Module\u003c/code\u003e, Keras Layers and models).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.vectorized_map\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded an optional parameter: \u003ccode\u003ewarn\u003c/code\u003e. This parameter controls whether or\nnot warnings will be printed when operations in the provided \u003ccode\u003efn\u003c/code\u003e fall\nback to a while loop.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eXLA:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.MultiWorkerMirroredStrategy\u003c/code\u003e is now compilable with XLA.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/ARM-software/ComputeLibrary\"\u003eCompute Library for the Arm® Architecture (ACL)\u003c/a\u003e\nis supported for aarch64 CPU XLA runtime\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eCPU performance optimizations:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ex86 CPUs\u003c/strong\u003e:\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/community/blob/master/rfcs/20210930-enable-onednn-ops.md\"\u003eoneDNN\u003c/a\u003e\nbfloat16 auto-mixed precision grappler graph optimization pass has been\nrenamed from \u003ccode\u003eauto_mixed_precision_mkl\u003c/code\u003e to\n\u003ccode\u003eauto_mixed_precision_onednn_bfloat16\u003c/code\u003e. See example usage\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/developer/articles/guide/getting-started-with-automixedprecisionmkl.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eaarch64 CPUs:\u003c/strong\u003e Experimental performance optimizations from\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/ARM-software/ComputeLibrary\"\u003eCompute Library for the Arm® Architecture (ACL)\u003c/a\u003e\nare available through oneDNN in the default Linux aarch64 package (\u003ccode\u003epip install tensorflow\u003c/code\u003e).\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe optimizations are disabled by default.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSet the environment variable \u003ccode\u003eTF_ENABLE_ONEDNN_OPTS=1\u003c/code\u003e to enable the\noptimizations. Setting the variable to 0 or unsetting it will\ndisable the optimizations.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThese optimizations can yield slightly different numerical results\nfrom when they are off due to floating-point round-off errors from\ndifferent computation approaches and orders.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTo verify that the optimizations are on, look for a message with\n\"\u003cem\u003eoneDNN custom operations are on\u003c/em\u003e\" in the log. If the exact phrase\nis not there, it means they are off.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\"
