2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDue to security issues in TF 2.8, all boosted trees code has now been removed (after being deprecated in TF 2.8). Users should switch to \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/decision-forests\"\u003eTensorFlow Decision Forests\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBuild, Compilation and Packaging\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTensorFlow is now compiled with \u003ccode\u003e_GLIBCXX_USE_CXX11_ABI=1\u003c/code\u003e. Downstream projects that encounter \u003ccode\u003estd::__cxx11\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003e[abi:cxx11]\u003c/code\u003e linker errors will need to adopt this compiler option. See \u003ca href=\"https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/libstdc++/manual/using_dual_abi.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ethe GNU C++ Library docs on Dual ABI\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTensorFlow Python wheels now specifically conform to \u003ca href=\"https://peps.python.org/pep-0599/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003emanylinux2014\u003c/a\u003e, an upgrade from manylinux2010. The minimum Pip version supporting manylinux2014 is Pip 19.3 (see \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/pypa/manylinux\"\u003epypa/manylinux\u003c/a\u003e. This change may affect you if you have been using TensorFlow on a very old platform equivalent to CentOS 6, as manylinux2014 targets CentOS 7 as a compatibility base. Note that TensorFlow does not officially support either platform.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDiscussion for these changes can be found on SIG Build's \u003ca href=\"https://discuss.tensorflow.org/t/tensorflow-linux-wheels-are-being-upgraded-to-manylinux2014/8339\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eTensorFlow Community Forum thread\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision.experimental\u003c/code\u003e API has been removed. The non-experimental symbols under \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision\u003c/code\u003e have been available since TensorFlow 2.4 and should be used instead.\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe non-experimental API has some minor differences from the experimental API. In most cases, you only need to make three minor changes:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRemove the word \"experimental\" from \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision\u003c/code\u003e symbols. E.g., replace \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision.experimental.global_policy\u003c/code\u003e with \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision.global_policy\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eReplace \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision.experimental.set_policy\u003c/code\u003e with \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision.set_global_policy\u003c/code\u003e. The experimental symbol \u003ccode\u003eset_policy\u003c/code\u003e was renamed to \u003ccode\u003eset_global_policy\u003c/code\u003e in the non-experimental API.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eReplace \u003ccode\u003eLossScaleOptimizer(opt, \"dynamic\")\u003c/code\u003e with \u003ccode\u003eLossScaleOptimizer(opt)\u003c/code\u003e. If you pass anything other than \u003ccode\u003e\"dynamic\"\u003c/code\u003e to the second argument, see (1) of the next section.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIn the following rare cases, you need to make more changes when switching to the non-experimental API:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIf you passed anything other than \u003ccode\u003e\"dynamic\"\u003c/code\u003e to the \u003ccode\u003eloss_scale\u003c/code\u003e argument (the second argument) of \u003ccode\u003eLossScaleOptimizer\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe LossScaleOptimizer constructor takes in different arguments. See the \u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/versions/r2.7/api_docs/python/tf/keras/mixed_precision/experimental/LossScaleOptimizer\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eTF 2.7 documentation of tf.keras.mixed_precision.experimental.LossScaleOptimizer\u003c/a\u003e for details on the differences, which has examples on how to convert to the non-experimental LossScaleOptimizer.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIf you passed a value to the \u003ccode\u003eloss_scale\u003c/code\u003e argument (the second argument) of \u003ccode\u003ePolicy\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe experimental version of \u003ccode\u003ePolicy\u003c/code\u003e optionally took in a \u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v1.mixed_precision.LossScale\u003c/code\u003e in the constructor, which defaulted to a dynamic loss scale for the \u003ccode\u003e\"mixed_float16\"\u003c/code\u003e policy and no loss scale for other policies. In \u003ccode\u003eModel.compile\u003c/code\u003e, if the model's policy had a loss scale, the optimizer would be wrapped with a \u003ccode\u003eLossScaleOptimizer\u003c/code\u003e. With the non-experimental \u003ccode\u003ePolicy\u003c/code\u003e, there is no loss scale associated with the \u003ccode\u003ePolicy\u003c/code\u003e, and \u003ccode\u003eModel.compile\u003c/code\u003e wraps the optimizer with a \u003ccode\u003eLossScaleOptimizer\u003c/code\u003e if and only if the policy is a \u003ccode\u003e\"mixed_float16\"\u003c/code\u003e policy. If you previously passed a \u003ccode\u003eLossScale\u003c/code\u003e to the experimental \u003ccode\u003ePolicy\u003c/code\u003e, consider just removing it, as the default loss scaling behavior is usually what you want. If you really want to customize the loss scaling behavior, you can wrap your optimizer with a \u003ccode\u003eLossScaleOptimizer\u003c/code\u003e before passing it to \u003ccode\u003eModel.compile\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIf you use the very rarely-used function \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision.experimental.get_layer_policy\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eReplace \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision.experimental.get_layer_policy(layer)\u003c/code\u003e with \u003ccode\u003elayer.dtype_policy\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.mixed_precision.experimental.LossScale\u003c/code\u003e and its subclasses have been removed from the TF2 namespace. This symbols were very rarely used and were only useful in TF2 for use in the now-removed \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision.experimental\u003c/code\u003e API. The symbols are still available under \u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v1.mixed_precision\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe \u003ccode\u003eexperimental_relax_shapes\u003c/code\u003e heuristic for \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e has been deprecated and replaced with \u003ccode\u003ereduce_retracing\u003c/code\u003e which encompasses broader heuristics to reduce the number of retraces (see below)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-major-features-and-improvements-12\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" href=\"#major-features-and-improvements-12\"\u003eMajor Features and Improvements\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.applications.resnet_rs\u003c/code\u003e models. This includes the\n\u003ccode\u003eResNetRS50\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eResNetRS101\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eResNetRS152\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eResNetRS200\u003c/code\u003e,\n\u003ccode\u003eResNetRS270\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eResNetRS350\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eResNetRS420\u003c/code\u003e model architectures. The\nResNetRS models are based on the architecture described in\n\u003ca href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/2103.07579.pdf\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eRevisiting ResNets: Improved Training and Scaling Strategies\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.experimental.Optimizer\u003c/code\u003e. The reworked\noptimizer gives more control over different phases of optimizer calls,\nand is easier to customize. We provide Adam, SGD, Adadelta, AdaGrad and\nRMSprop optimizers based on\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.experimental.Optimizer\u003c/code\u003e. Generally the new\noptimizers work in the same way as the old ones, but support new\nconstructor arguments. In the future, the symbols\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.Optimizer\u003c/code\u003e/\u003ccode\u003eAdam\u003c/code\u003e/etc will point to the new\noptimizers, and the previous generation of optimizers will be moved to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.legacy.Optimizer\u003c/code\u003e/\u003ccode\u003eAdam\u003c/code\u003e/etc.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded L2 unit normalization layer \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.layers.UnitNormalization\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.regularizers.OrthogonalRegularizer\u003c/code\u003e, a new regularizer\nthat encourages orthogonality between the rows (or columns) or a weight\nmatrix.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.layers.RandomBrightness\u003c/code\u003e layer for image preprocessing.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded APIs for switching between interactive logging and absl logging.\nBy default, Keras always writes the logs to stdout. However, this is not\noptimal in a non-interactive environment, where you don't have access to\nstdout, but can only view the logs. You can use\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.utils.disable_interactive_logging()\u003c/code\u003e to write the logs to ABSL\nlogging. You can also use \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.utils.enable_interactive_logging()\u003c/code\u003e\nto change it back to stdout, or\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.utils.is_interactive_logging_enabled()\u003c/code\u003e to check if\ninteractive logging is enabled.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eChanged default value for the \u003ccode\u003everbose\u003c/code\u003e argument of \u003ccode\u003eModel.evaluate()\u003c/code\u003e\nand \u003ccode\u003eModel.predict()\u003c/code\u003e to \u003ccode\u003e\"auto\"\u003c/code\u003e, which defaults to \u003ccode\u003everbose=1\u003c/code\u003e for\nmost cases and defaults to \u003ccode\u003everbose=2\u003c/code\u003e when used with\n\u003ccode\u003eParameterServerStrategy\u003c/code\u003e or with interactive logging disabled.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eArgument \u003ccode\u003ejit_compile\u003c/code\u003e in \u003ccode\u003eModel.compile()\u003c/code\u003e now applies to\n\u003ccode\u003eModel.evaluate()\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eModel.predict()\u003c/code\u003e. Setting \u003ccode\u003ejit_compile=True\u003c/code\u003e in\n\u003ccode\u003ecompile()\u003c/code\u003e compiles the model's training, evaluation, and inference\nsteps to \u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/xla\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eXLA\u003c/a\u003e. Note that\n\u003ccode\u003ejit_compile=True\u003c/code\u003e may not necessarily work for all models.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded DTensor-related Keras APIs under \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.dtensor\u003c/code\u003e namespace. The\nAPIs are still classified as experimental. You are welcome to try it\nout. Please check the tutorial and guide on \u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ehttps://www.tensorflow.org/\u003c/a\u003e\nfor more details about DTensor.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.lite\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded TFLite builtin op support for the following TF ops:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.math.argmin\u003c/code\u003e/\u003ccode\u003etf.math.argmax\u003c/code\u003e for input data type \u003ccode\u003etf.bool\u003c/code\u003e on\nCPU.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.nn.gelu\u003c/code\u003e op for output data type \u003ccode\u003etf.float32\u003c/code\u003e and quantization\non CPU.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd nominal support for unsigned 16-bit integer tensor types. Note that\nvery few TFLite kernels support this type natively, so its use in mobile\nML authoring is generally discouraged.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd support for unsigned 16-bit integer tensor types in cast op.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eExperimental support for lowering \u003ccode\u003elist_ops.tensor_list_set_item\u003c/code\u003e with\n\u003ccode\u003eDynamicUpdateSlice\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEnabled a new MLIR-based dynamic range quantization backend by default\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe new backend is used for post-training int8 dynamic range\nquantization and post-training float16 quantization.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSet \u003ccode\u003eexperimental_new_dynamic_range_quantizer\u003c/code\u003e in\ntf.lite.TFLiteConverter to False to disable this change\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNative TF Lite variables are now enabled during conversion by default on\nall v2 TfLiteConverter entry points.\n\u003ccode\u003eexperimental_enable_resource_variables\u003c/code\u003e on tf.lite.TFLiteConverter is\nnow True by default and will be removed in the future.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCustom classes used as arguments for \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e can now specify rules\nregarding when retracing needs to occur by implementing the Tracing\nProtocol available through\n\u003ccode\u003etf.types.experimental.SupportsTracingProtocol\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eTypeSpec\u003c/code\u003e classes (as associated with \u003ccode\u003eExtensionTypes\u003c/code\u003e) also implement\nthe Tracing Protocol which can be overridden if necessary.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe newly introduced \u003ccode\u003ereduce_retracing\u003c/code\u003e option also uses the Tracing\nProtocol to proactively generate generalized traces similar to\n\u003ccode\u003eexperimental_relax_shapes\u003c/code\u003e (which has now been deprecated).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eUnified eager and \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e execution:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEager mode can now execute each op as a \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e, allowing for more\nconsistent feature support in future releases.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIt is available for immediate use.\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSee the \u003ccode\u003eTF_RUN_EAGER_OP_AS_FUNCTION\u003c/code\u003e environment variable in\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/python/eager/context.py\"\u003eeager context\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEager performance should be similar with this feature enabled.\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eA roughly 5us per-op overhead may be observed when running many\nsmall functions.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNote a\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/55414\" data-hovercard-type=\"issue\" data-hovercard-url=\"/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/55414/hovercard\"\u003eknown issue\u003c/a\u003e\nwith GPU performance.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe behavior of \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e itself is unaffected.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNote: This feature will be enabled by default in an upcoming version of\nTensorFlow.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.experimental.dtensor\u003c/code\u003e: Added DTensor, an extension to TensorFlow for\nlarge-scale modeling with minimal changes to user code. You are welcome to\ntry it out, though be aware that the DTensor API is experimental and up-to\nbackward-incompatible changes. DTensor and Keras integration is published\nunder \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.dtensor\u003c/code\u003e in this release (refer to the \u003ccode\u003etf.keras\u003c/code\u003e entry).\nThe tutoral and guide for DTensor will be published on\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ehttps://www.tensorflow.org/\u003c/a\u003e. Please stay tuned.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/community/blob/master/rfcs/20210930-enable-onednn-ops.md\"\u003eoneDNN CPU performance optimizations\u003c/a\u003e\nare available in Linux x86, Windows x86, and Linux aarch64 packages.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLinux x86 packages:\u003c/strong\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eoneDNN optimizations are \u003cem\u003eenabled by default\u003c/em\u003e on CPUs with\nneural-network-focused hardware features such as AVX512_VNNI,\nAVX512_BF16, AMX, etc.\n(\u003ca href=\"https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/products/platforms/details/cascade-lake.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eIntel Cascade Lake\u003c/a\u003e\nand newer CPUs.)\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://medium.com/intel-analytics-software/leverage-intel-deep-learning-optimizations-in-tensorflow-129faa80ee07\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eExample performance speedups.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFor older CPUs, oneDNN optimizations are disabled by default.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWindows x86 package:\u003c/strong\u003e oneDNN optimizations are disabled by default.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLinux aach64 (\u003ccode\u003e--config=mkl_aarch64\u003c/code\u003e) package:\u003c/strong\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eExperimental oneDNN optimizations are disabled by default.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIf you experience issues with oneDNN optimizations on, we recommend\nturning them off.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTo explicitly enable or disable oneDNN optimizations, set the\nenvironment variable \u003ccode\u003eTF_ENABLE_ONEDNN_OPTS\u003c/code\u003e to \u003ccode\u003e1\u003c/code\u003e (enable) or \u003ccode\u003e0\u003c/code\u003e\n(disable) before running TensorFlow. (The variable is checked during\n\u003ccode\u003eimport tensorflow\u003c/code\u003e.) To fall back to default settings, unset the\nenvironment variable.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThese optimizations can yield slightly different numerical results from\nwhen they are off due to floating-point round-off errors from different\ncomputation approaches and orders.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTo verify that the optimizations are on, look for a message with\n\u003cem\u003e\"oneDNN custom operations are on\"\u003c/em\u003e in the log. If the exact phrase is\nnot there, it means they are off.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-bug-fixes-and-other-changes-11\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" href=\"#bug-fixes-and-other-changes-11\"\u003eBug Fixes and Other Changes\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFixed bug in \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.parse_example_dataset\u003c/code\u003e when \u003ccode\u003etf.io.RaggedFeatures\u003c/code\u003e would specify \u003ccode\u003evalue_key\u003c/code\u003e but no \u003ccode\u003epartitions\u003c/code\u003e. Before the fix, setting \u003ccode\u003evalue_key\u003c/code\u003e but no \u003ccode\u003epartitions\u003c/code\u003e would result in the feature key being replaced by the value key, e.g. \u003ccode\u003e{'value_key': \u0026lt;RaggedTensor\u0026gt;}\u003c/code\u003e instead of \u003ccode\u003e{'key': \u0026lt;RaggedTensor\u0026gt;}\u003c/code\u003e. Now the correct feature key will be used. This aligns the behavior of \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.parse_example_dataset\u003c/code\u003e to match the behavior of \u003ccode\u003etf.io.parse_example\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded a new field, \u003ccode\u003efilter_parallelization\u003c/code\u003e, to \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.OptimizationOptions\u003c/code\u003e. If it is set to \u003ccode\u003eTrue\u003c/code\u003e, tf.data will run \u003ccode\u003eFilter\u003c/code\u003e transformation with multiple threads. Its default value is \u003ccode\u003eFalse\u003c/code\u003e if not specified.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp \u003ccode\u003eprecision_mode\u003c/code\u003e,\n\u003ccode\u003eminimum_segment_size\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003emaximum_cached_engines\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003euse_calibration\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003eallow_build_at_runtime\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded a new parameter called \u003ccode\u003esave_gpu_specific_engines\u003c/code\u003e to the\n\u003ccode\u003e.save()\u003c/code\u003e function inside \u003ccode\u003eTrtGraphConverterV2\u003c/code\u003e. When \u003ccode\u003eFalse\u003c/code\u003e, the\n\u003ccode\u003e.save()\u003c/code\u003e function won't save any TRT engines that have been built. When\n\u003ccode\u003eTrue\u003c/code\u003e (default), the original behavior is preserved.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eTrtGraphConverterV2\u003c/code\u003e provides a new API called \u003ccode\u003e.summary()\u003c/code\u003e which\noutputs a summary of the inference converted by TF-TRT. It namely shows\neach \u003ccode\u003eTRTEngineOp\u003c/code\u003e with their input(s)' and output(s)' shape and dtype.\nA detailed version of the summary is available which prints additionally\nall the TensorFlow OPs included in each of the \u003ccode\u003eTRTEngineOp\u003c/code\u003es.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.tpu.experimental.embedding\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.tpu.experimental.embedding.FeatureConfig\u003c/code\u003e now takes an additional\nargument \u003ccode\u003eoutput_shape\u003c/code\u003e which can specify the shape of the output\nactivation for the feature.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.tpu.experimental.embedding.TPUEmbedding\u003c/code\u003e now has the same behavior\nas \u003ccode\u003etf.tpu.experimental.embedding.serving_embedding_lookup\u003c/code\u003e which can\ntake arbitrary rank of dense and sparse tensor. For ragged tensor,\nthough the input tensor remains to be rank 2, the activations now can be\nrank 2 or above by specifying the output shape in the feature config or\nvia the build method.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAdd\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/config/experimental/enable_op_determinism\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.config.experimental.enable_op_determinism\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e,\nwhich makes TensorFlow ops run deterministically at the cost of performance.\nReplaces the \u003ccode\u003eTF_DETERMINISTIC_OPS\u003c/code\u003e environmental variable, which is now\ndeprecated. The \"Bug Fixes and Other Changes\" section lists more\ndeterminism-related changes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e(Since TF 2.7) Add\n\u003ca href=\"https://blog.tensorflow.org/2021/06/pluggabledevice-device-plugins-for-TensorFlow.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ePluggableDevice\u003c/a\u003e\nsupport to\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/community/blob/master/rfcs/20210513-pluggable-profiler-for-tensorflow.md\"\u003eTensorFlow Profiler\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-bug-fixes-and-other-changes-12\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" href=\"#bug-fixes-and-other-changes-12\"\u003eBug Fixes and Other Changes\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFixed a bug where setting \u003ccode\u003eoptions.deterministic = False\u003c/code\u003e would only\nmodify one transformation to run non-deterministically, leaving other\ntransformations deterministic. The option will now apply the same across\nall transformations.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe optimization \u003ccode\u003eparallel_batch\u003c/code\u003e now becomes default if not disabled by\nusers, which will parallelize copying of batch elements.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded the ability for \u003ccode\u003eTensorSliceDataset\u003c/code\u003e to identify and handle inputs\nthat are files. This enables creating hermetic SavedModels when using\ndatasets created from files.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.lite\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdds GPU Delegation support for serialization to Java API. This boosts\ninitialization time up to 90% when OpenCL is available.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDeprecated \u003ccode\u003eInterpreter::SetNumThreads\u003c/code\u003e, in favor of\n\u003ccode\u003eInterpreterBuilder::SetNumThreads\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdds \u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v1.keras.utils.get_or_create_layer\u003c/code\u003e to aid migration to\nTF2 by enabling tracking of nested keras models created in TF1-style,\nwhen used with the \u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v1.keras.utils.track_tf1_style_variables\u003c/code\u003e\ndecorator.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded a \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.layers.experimental.preprocessing.HashedCrossing\u003c/code\u003e\nlayer which applies the hashing trick to the concatenation of crossed\nscalar inputs. This provides a stateless way to try adding feature\ncrosses of integer or string data to a model.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRemoved \u003ccode\u003ekeras.layers.experimental.preprocessing.CategoryCrossing\u003c/code\u003e.\nUsers should migrate to the \u003ccode\u003eHashedCrossing\u003c/code\u003e layer or use\n\u003ccode\u003etf.sparse.cross\u003c/code\u003e/\u003ccode\u003etf.ragged.cross\u003c/code\u003e directly.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded additional \u003ccode\u003estandardize\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003esplit\u003c/code\u003e modes to \u003ccode\u003eTextVectorization\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003estandardize=\"lower\"\u003c/code\u003e will lowercase inputs.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003estandardize=\"string_punctuation\"\u003c/code\u003e will remove all punctuation.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003esplit=\"character\"\u003c/code\u003e will split on every unicode character.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded an \u003ccode\u003eoutput_mode\u003c/code\u003e argument to the \u003ccode\u003eDiscretization\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eHashing\u003c/code\u003e\nlayers with the same semantics as other preprocessing layers. All\ncategorical preprocessing layers now support \u003ccode\u003eoutput_mode\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAll preprocessing layer output will follow the compute dtype of a\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision.Policy\u003c/code\u003e, unless constructed with\n\u003ccode\u003eoutput_mode=\"int\"\u003c/code\u003e in which case output will be \u003ccode\u003etf.int64\u003c/code\u003e. The output\ntype of any preprocessing layer can be controlled individually by\npassing a \u003ccode\u003edtype\u003c/code\u003e argument to the layer.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.random.Generator\u003c/code\u003e for keras initializers and all RNG code.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded 3 new APIs for enable/disable/check the usage of\n\u003ccode\u003etf.random.Generator\u003c/code\u003e in keras backend, which will be the new backend\nfor all the RNG in Keras. We plan to switch on the new code path by\ndefault in tf 2.8, and the behavior change will likely to cause some\nbreakage on user side (eg if the test is checking against some golden\nnumber). These 3 APIs will allow user to disable and switch back to\nlegacy behavior if they prefer. In future (eg TF 2.10), we expect to\ntotally remove the legacy code path (stateful random Ops), and these 3\nAPIs will be removed as well.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.callbacks.experimental.BackupAndRestore\u003c/code\u003e is now available as\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.callbacks.BackupAndRestore\u003c/code\u003e. The experimental endpoint is\ndeprecated and will be removed in a future release.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.experimental.SidecarEvaluator\u003c/code\u003e is now available as\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.utils.SidecarEvaluator\u003c/code\u003e. The experimental endpoint is\ndeprecated and will be removed in a future release.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMetrics update and collection logic in default \u003ccode\u003eModel.train_step()\u003c/code\u003e is\nnow customizable via overriding \u003ccode\u003eModel.compute_metrics()\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLosses computation logic in default \u003ccode\u003eModel.train_step()\u003c/code\u003e is now\ncustomizable via overriding \u003ccode\u003eModel.compute_loss()\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003ejit_compile\u003c/code\u003e added to \u003ccode\u003eModel.compile()\u003c/code\u003e on an opt-in basis to compile\nthe model's training step with \u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/xla\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eXLA\u003c/a\u003e.\nNote that \u003ccode\u003ejit_compile=True\u003c/code\u003e may not necessarily work for all models.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eDeterministic Op Functionality:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFix regression in deterministic selection of deterministic cuDNN\nconvolution algorithms, a regression that was introduced in v2.5. Note\nthat nondeterministic out-of-memory events while selecting algorithms\ncould still lead to nondeterminism, although this is very unlikely. This\nadditional, unlikely source will be eliminated in a later version.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd deterministic GPU implementations of:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.function(jit_compile=True)\u003c/code\u003e's that use \u003ccode\u003eScatter\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) Stateful ops used in \u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.convert_to_tensor\u003c/code\u003e when fed with (sparse)\n\u003ccode\u003etf.IndexedSlices\u003c/code\u003e (because it uses \u003ccode\u003etf.math.unsorted_segment_sum\u003c/code\u003e)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.gather\u003c/code\u003e backprop (because \u003ccode\u003etf.convert_to_tensor\u003c/code\u003e\nreduces \u003ccode\u003etf.gather\u003c/code\u003e's (sparse) \u003ccode\u003etf.IndexedSlices\u003c/code\u003e gradients into its\ndense \u003ccode\u003eparams\u003c/code\u003e input)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.math.segment_mean\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.math.segment_prod\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.math.segment_sum\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.math.unsorted_segment_mean\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.math.unsorted_segment_prod\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.math.unsorted_segment_sum\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.math.unsorted_segment_sqrt\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.nn.ctc_loss\u003c/code\u003e (resolved, possibly in prior release,\nand confirmed with tests)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7)\u003ccode\u003etf.nn.sparse_softmax_crossentropy_with_logits\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) Run \u003ccode\u003etf.scatter_nd\u003c/code\u003e and other related scatter functions,\nsuch as \u003ccode\u003etf.tensor_scatter_nd_update\u003c/code\u003e, on CPU (with significant\nperformance penalty).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd determinism-unimplemented exception-throwing to the following ops.\nWhen op-determinism is expected (i.e. after\n\u003ccode\u003etf.config.experimental.enable_op_determinism\u003c/code\u003e has been called), an\nattempt to use the specified paths through the following ops on a GPU\nwill cause \u003ccode\u003etf.errors.UnimplementedError\u003c/code\u003e (with an understandable\nmessage), unless otherwise specified, to be thrown.\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eFakeQuantWithMinMaxVarsGradient\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003eFakeQuantWithMinMaxVarsPerChannelGradient\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v1.get_seed\u003c/code\u003e if the global random seed has\nnot yet been set (via \u003ccode\u003etf.random.set_seed\u003c/code\u003e). Throws \u003ccode\u003eRuntimeError\u003c/code\u003e\nfrom Python or \u003ccode\u003eInvalidArgument\u003c/code\u003e from C++\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v1.nn.fused_batch_norm\u003c/code\u003e backprop to \u003ccode\u003eoffset\u003c/code\u003e\nwhen \u003ccode\u003eis_training=False\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.image.adjust_contrast\u003c/code\u003e forward\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.image.resize\u003c/code\u003e with \u003ccode\u003emethod=ResizeMethod.NEAREST\u003c/code\u003e\nbackprop\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.linalg.svd\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.math.bincount\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.nn.depthwise_conv2d\u003c/code\u003e backprop to \u003ccode\u003efilter\u003c/code\u003e when not\nusing cuDNN convolution\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.nn.dilation2d\u003c/code\u003e gradient\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.nn.max_pool_with_argmax\u003c/code\u003e gradient\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.raw_ops.DebugNumericSummary\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003etf.raw_ops.DebugNumericSummaryV2\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.timestamp\u003c/code\u003e. Throws \u003ccode\u003eFailedPrecondition\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) \u003ccode\u003etf.Variable.scatter_add\u003c/code\u003e (and other scatter methods,\nboth on ref and resource variables)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(since v2.7) The random-number-generating ops in the \u003ccode\u003etf.random\u003c/code\u003e\nmodule when the global random seed has not yet been set (via\n\u003ccode\u003etf.random.set_seed\u003c/code\u003e). dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe methods \u003ccode\u003eModel.fit()\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eModel.predict()\u003c/code\u003e, and \u003ccode\u003eModel.evaluate()\u003c/code\u003e\nwill no longer uprank input data of shape \u003ccode\u003e(batch_size,)\u003c/code\u003e to become\n\u003ccode\u003e(batch_size, 1)\u003c/code\u003e. This enables \u003ccode\u003eModel\u003c/code\u003e subclasses to process scalar\ndata in their \u003ccode\u003etrain_step()\u003c/code\u003e/\u003ccode\u003etest_step()\u003c/code\u003e/\u003ccode\u003epredict_step()\u003c/code\u003e methods. \u003cbr\u003e\nNote that this change may break certain subclassed models. You can\nrevert back to the previous behavior by adding upranking yourself in the\n\u003ccode\u003etrain_step()\u003c/code\u003e/\u003ccode\u003etest_step()\u003c/code\u003e/\u003ccode\u003epredict_step()\u003c/code\u003e methods, e.g. \u003ccode\u003eif x.shape.rank == 1: x = tf.expand_dims(x, axis=-1)\u003c/code\u003e. Functional models as\nwell as Sequential models built with an explicit input shape are not\naffected.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe methods \u003ccode\u003eModel.to_yaml()\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003ekeras.models.model_from_yaml\u003c/code\u003e have\nbeen replaced to raise a \u003ccode\u003eRuntimeError\u003c/code\u003e as they can be abused to cause\narbitrary code execution. It is recommended to use JSON serialization\ninstead of YAML, or, a better alternative, serialize to H5.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eLinearModel\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eWideDeepModel\u003c/code\u003e are moved to the\n\u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v1.keras.models.\u003c/code\u003e namespace\n(\u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v1.keras.models.LinearModel\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v1.keras.models.WideDeepModel\u003c/code\u003e), and their \u003ccode\u003eexperimental\u003c/code\u003e\nendpoints (\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.experimental.models.LinearModel\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.experimental.models.WideDeepModel\u003c/code\u003e) are being deprecated.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRNG behavior change for all \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.initializers\u003c/code\u003e classes. For any\nclass constructed with a fixed seed, it will no longer generate same\nvalue when invoked multiple times. Instead, it will return different\nvalue, but a deterministic sequence. This change will make the\ninitialize behavior align between v1 and v2.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.lite\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRename fields \u003ccode\u003eSignatureDef\u003c/code\u003e table in schema to maximize the parity with\nTF SavedModel's Signature concept.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDeprecate Makefile builds. Makefile users need to migrate their builds\nto CMake or Bazel. Please refer to the\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/lite/guide/build_cmake\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eBuild TensorFlow Lite with CMake\u003c/a\u003e\nand\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/lite/guide/build_arm\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eBuild TensorFlow Lite for ARM boards\u003c/a\u003e\nfor the migration.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDeprecate \u003ccode\u003etflite::OpResolver::GetDelegates\u003c/code\u003e. The list returned by\nTfLite's \u003ccode\u003eBuiltinOpResolver::GetDelegates\u003c/code\u003e is now always empty. Instead,\nrecommend using new method \u003ccode\u003etflite::OpResolver::GetDelegateCreators\u003c/code\u003e in\norder to achieve lazy initialization on TfLite delegate instances.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTF Core:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.Graph.get_name_scope()\u003c/code\u003e now always returns a string, as documented.\nPreviously, when called within \u003ccode\u003ename_scope(\"\")\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003ename_scope(None)\u003c/code\u003e\ncontexts, it returned \u003ccode\u003eNone\u003c/code\u003e; now it returns the empty string.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etensorflow/core/ir/\u003c/code\u003e contains a new MLIR-based Graph dialect that is\nisomorphic to GraphDef and will be used to replace GraphDef-based (e.g.,\nGrappler) optimizations.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDeprecated and removed \u003ccode\u003eattrs()\u003c/code\u003e function in shape inference. All\nattributes should be queried by name now (rather than range returned) to\nenable changing the underlying storage there.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe following Python symbols were accidentally added in earlier versions\nof TensorFlow and now are removed. Each symbol has a replacement that\nshould be used instead, but note the replacement's argument names are\ndifferent.\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.quantize_and_dequantize_v4\u003c/code\u003e (accidentally introduced in\nTensorFlow 2.4): Use \u003ccode\u003etf.quantization.quantize_and_dequantize_v2\u003c/code\u003e\ninstead.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.batch_mat_mul_v3\u003c/code\u003e (accidentally introduced in TensorFlow 2.6):\nUse \u003ccode\u003etf.linalg.matmul\u003c/code\u003e instead.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.sparse_segment_sum_grad\u003c/code\u003e (accidentally introduced in TensorFlow\n2.6): Use \u003ccode\u003etf.raw_ops.SparseSegmentSumGrad\u003c/code\u003e instead. Directly\ncalling this op is typically not necessary, as it is automatically\nused when computing the gradient of \u003ccode\u003etf.sparse.segment_sum\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRenaming of tensorflow::int64 to int_64_t in numerous places (the former\nis an alias for the latter) which could result in needing to regenerate\nselective op registration headers else execution would fail with\nunregistered kernels error.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eModular File System Migration:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSupport for S3 and HDFS file systems has been migrated to a modular file\nsystems based approach and is now available in\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/io\"\u003ehttps://github.com/tensorflow/io\u003c/a\u003e. The \u003ccode\u003etensorflow-io\u003c/code\u003e python package\nshould be installed for S3 and HDFS support with tensorflow.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-major-features-and-improvements-14\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" href=\"#major-features-and-improvements-14\"\u003eMajor Features and Improvements\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eImprovements to the TensorFlow debugging experience:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePreviously, TensorFlow error stack traces involved many internal frames,\nwhich could be challenging to read through, while not being actionable\nfor end users. As of TF 2.7, TensorFlow filters internal frames in most\nerrors that it raises, to keep stack traces short, readable, and focused\non what's actionable for end users (their own code).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis behavior can be disabled by calling\n\u003ccode\u003etf.debugging.disable_traceback_filtering()\u003c/code\u003e, and can be re-enabled via\n\u003ccode\u003etf.debugging.enable_traceback_filtering()\u003c/code\u003e. If you are debugging a\nTensorFlow-internal issue (e.g. to prepare a TensorFlow PR), make sure to\ndisable traceback filtering. You can check whether this feature is currently\nenabled by calling \u003ccode\u003etf.debugging.is_traceback_filtering_enabled()\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eNote that this feature is only available with Python 3.7 or higher.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eImprove the informativeness of error messages raised by Keras\n\u003ccode\u003eLayer.__call__()\u003c/code\u003e, by adding the full list of argument values passed to\nthe layer in every exception.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIntroduce the \u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v1.keras.utils.track_tf1_style_variables\u003c/code\u003e\ndecorator, which enables using large classes of tf1-style variable_scope,\n\u003ccode\u003eget_variable\u003c/code\u003e, and \u003ccode\u003ecompat.v1.layer\u003c/code\u003e-based components from within TF2\nmodels running with TF2 behavior enabled.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003etf.data service now supports auto-sharding. Users specify the sharding\npolicy with \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.service.ShardingPolicy\u003c/code\u003e enum. It can\nbe one of \u003ccode\u003eOFF\u003c/code\u003e (equivalent to today's \u003ccode\u003e\"parallel_epochs\"\u003c/code\u003e mode),\n\u003ccode\u003eDYNAMIC\u003c/code\u003e (equivalent to today's \u003ccode\u003e\"distributed_epoch\"\u003c/code\u003e mode), or one of\nthe static sharding policies: \u003ccode\u003eFILE\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eDATA\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eFILE_OR_DATA\u003c/code\u003e, or \u003ccode\u003eHINT\u003c/code\u003e\n(corresponding to values of \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.AutoShardPolicy\u003c/code\u003e).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eStatic sharding (auto-sharding) requires the number of tf.data service\nworkers be fixed. Users need to specify the worker addresses in\n\u003ccode\u003etensorflow.data.experimental.DispatcherConfig\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.service.register_dataset\u003c/code\u003e now accepts optional\n\u003ccode\u003ecompression\u003c/code\u003e argument.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eKeras:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.layers.Conv\u003c/code\u003e now includes a public \u003ccode\u003econvolution_op\u003c/code\u003e method.\nThis method can be used to simplify the implementation of Conv\nsubclasses. There are two primary ways to use this new method. The first\nis to use the method directly in your own \u003ccode\u003ecall\u003c/code\u003e method: \u003ccode\u003epython class StandardizedConv2D(tf.keras.layers.Conv2D): def call(self, inputs): mean, var = tf.nn.moments(self.kernel, axes=[0, 1, 2], keepdims=True) return self.convolution_op(inputs, (self.kernel - mean) / tf.sqrt(var + 1e-10))\u003c/code\u003e Alternatively, you can override \u003ccode\u003econvolution_op\u003c/code\u003e: \u003ccode\u003epython class StandardizedConv2D(tf.keras.Layer): def convolution_op(self, inputs, kernel): mean, var = tf.nn.moments(kernel, axes=[0, 1, 2], keepdims=True) # Author code uses std + 1e-5 return super().convolution_op(inputs, (kernel - mean) / tf.sqrt(var + 1e-10))\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003emerge_state()\u003c/code\u003e method to \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.metrics.Metric\u003c/code\u003e for use in\ndistributed computations.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003esparse\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eragged\u003c/code\u003e options to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.layers.TextVectorization\u003c/code\u003e to allow for \u003ccode\u003eSparseTensor\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003eRaggedTensor\u003c/code\u003e outputs from the layer.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003edistribute.experimental.rpc package:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003edistribute.experimental.rpc package introduces APIs to create a GRPC\nbased server to register tf.function methods and a GRPC client to invoke\nremote registered methods. RPC APIs are intended for multi-client setups\ni.e. server and clients are started in separate binaries independently.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eExample usage to create server: ```python server =\ntf.distribute.experimental.rpc.Server.create(\"grpc\", \"127.0.0.1:1234\")\n@tf.function(input_signature=[ tf.TensorSpec([], tf.int32),\ntf.TensorSpec([], dtypes.int32) ]) def _remote_multiply(a, b): return\ntf.math.multiply(a, b)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eserver.register(\"multiply\", _remote_multiply) ```\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eExample usage to create client: \u003ccode\u003epython client = tf.distribute.experimental.rpc.Client.create(\"grpc\", address) a = tf.constant(2, dtype=tf.int32) b = tf.constant(3, dtype=tf.int32) result = client.multiply(a, b)\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.lite\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd experimental API \u003ccode\u003eexperimental_from_jax\u003c/code\u003e to support conversion from\nJax models to TensorFlow Lite.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSupport uint32 data type for cast op.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSupport int8 data type for cast op.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd experimental quantization debugger \u003ccode\u003etf.lite.QuantizationDebugger\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd lite.experimental.authoring.compatible API\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eA Python decorator to provide a way to check TFLite compatibility\nissue of \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e. This returns a callable object which\nvalidates TFLite compatibility. If an incompatible operation is\nencountered during execution, an exception will be raised with\ninformation about the incompatible ops.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd lite.experimental.Analyzer API\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAn experimental tool to analyze TFLite flatbuffer models. This API\ncan be used to investigate TFLite model structure and check\ncompatibility with GPU delegate.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eExtension Types\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd experimental API to define new Python classes that can be handled by\nTensorFlow APIs. To create an extension type, simply define a Python\nclass with \u003ccode\u003etf.experimental.ExtensionType\u003c/code\u003e as its base, and use type\nannotations to specify the type for each field. E.g.: \u003ccode\u003epython class MaskedTensor(tf.experimental.ExtensionType): values: tf.Tensor mask: tf.Tensor\u003c/code\u003e The \u003ccode\u003etf.ExtensionType\u003c/code\u003e base class works similarly to\n\u003ca href=\"https://docs.python.org/3/library/typing.html#typing.NamedTuple\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etyping.NamedTuple\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\nand\n\u003ca href=\"https://docs.python.org/3/library/dataclasses.html#dataclasses.dataclass\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e@dataclasses.dataclass\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\nfrom the standard Python library.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eExtension types are supported by Keras, tf.data, TF-hub, SavedModel,\ntf.function, control flow ops, py_function, and distribution strategy.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd \"dispatch decorators\" that can be used to override the default\nbehavior of TensorFlow ops (such as \u003ccode\u003etf.add\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003etf.concat\u003c/code\u003e) when they\nare applied to ExtensionType values.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe \u003ccode\u003eBatchableExtensionType\u003c/code\u003e API can be used to define extension types\nthat support APIs that make use of batching, such as \u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset\u003c/code\u003e\nand \u003ccode\u003etf.map_fn\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFor more information, see the\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/guide/extension_type\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eExtension types guide\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-bug-fixes-and-other-changes-13\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" href=\"#bug-fixes-and-other-changes-13\"\u003eBug Fixes and Other Changes\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTF Core:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRandom number generation (RNG) system\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd argument \u003ccode\u003ealg\u003c/code\u003e to \u003ccode\u003etf.random.stateless_*\u003c/code\u003e functions to\nexplicitly select the RNG algorithm.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd \u003ccode\u003etf.nn.experimental.stateless_dropout\u003c/code\u003e, a stateless version of\n\u003ccode\u003etf.nn.dropout\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.random.Generator\u003c/code\u003e now can be created inside the scope of\n\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.experimental.ParameterServerStrategy\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.experimental.CentralStorageStrategy\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd an experimental session config\n\u003ccode\u003etf.experimental.disable_functional_ops_lowering\u003c/code\u003e which disables\nfunctional control flow op lowering optimization. This is useful when\nexecuting within a portable runtime where control flow op kernels may\nnot be loaded due to selective registration.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd a new experimental argument \u003ccode\u003eexperimental_is_anonymous\u003c/code\u003e to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.lookup.StaticHashTable.__init__\u003c/code\u003e to create the table in anonymous\nmode. In this mode, the table resource can only be accessed via resource\nhandles (not resource names) and will be deleted automatically when all\nresource handles pointing to it are gone.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIntroduce the \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.at\u003c/code\u003e API which provides random access\nfor input pipelines that consist of transformations that support random\naccess. The initial set of transformations that support random access\nincludes:\n\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.from_tensor_slices\u003c/code\u003e,\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.shuffle\u003c/code\u003e,\n\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.batch\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.shard\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.map\u003c/code\u003e,\nand \u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.range\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePromote \u003ccode\u003etf.data.Options.experimental_deterministic\u003c/code\u003e API to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Options.deterministic\u003c/code\u003e and deprecate the experimental endpoint.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMove autotuning options\nfrom\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Options.experimental_optimization.autotune*\u003c/code\u003e to a newly\ncreated \u003ccode\u003etf.data.Options.autotune.*\u003c/code\u003e and remove support for\n\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Options.experimental_optimization.autotune_buffers\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd support for user-defined names of tf.data core Python API, which can\nbe used to disambiguate tf.data events in TF Profiler Trace Viewer.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePromote \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.sample_from_datasets\u003c/code\u003e API to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.sample_from_datasets\u003c/code\u003e and deprecate the experimental\nendpoint.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003eTF_GPU_ALLOCATOR=cuda_malloc_async\u003c/code\u003e that use cudaMallocAsync from\nCUDA 11.2. This could become the default in the future.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTF SavedModel:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCustom gradients are now saved by default. See\n\u003ccode\u003etf.saved_model.SaveOptions\u003c/code\u003e to disable this.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe saved_model_cli's \u003ccode\u003e--input_examples\u003c/code\u003e inputs are now restricted to\npython literals to avoid code injection.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eXLA:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd a new API that allows custom call functions to signal errors. The\nold API will be deprecated in a future release. See\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/xla/custom_call\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ehttps://www.tensorflow.org/xla/custom_call\u003c/a\u003e for details.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eXLA:GPU reductions are deterministic by default (reductions within\n\u003ccode\u003ejit_compile=True\u003c/code\u003e are now deterministic).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eXLA:GPU works with Horovod (OSS The function is\nstill accessible under\n\u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v1.mixed_precision.enable_mixed_precision_graph_rewrite\u003c/code\u003e, but it\nis recommended to use the\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/guide/mixed_precision\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eKeras mixed precision API\u003c/a\u003e\ninstead.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.lite\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRemove \u003ccode\u003eexperimental.nn.dynamic_rnn\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eexperimental.nn.TfLiteRNNCell\u003c/code\u003e\nand \u003ccode\u003eexperimental.nn.TfLiteLSTMCell\u003c/code\u003e since they're no longer supported.\nIt's recommended to just use\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/keras/layers/LSTM\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ekeras lstm\u003c/a\u003e\ninstead.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eKeras been split into a separate PIP package (\u003ccode\u003ekeras\u003c/code\u003e), and its code has\nbeen moved to the GitHub\nrepository\u003ca href=\"http://github.com/keras-team/keras\"\u003ekeras-team/keras\u003c/a\u003e. The\nAPI endpoints for \u003ccode\u003etf.keras\u003c/code\u003e stay unchanged, but are now backed by the\n\u003ccode\u003ekeras\u003c/code\u003e PIP package. The existing code in tensorflow/python/keras is a\nstaled copy and will be removed in future release (2.7). Please remove\nany imports to \u003ccode\u003etensorflow.python.keras\u003c/code\u003e and replace them with public\ntf.keras API instead.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe methods \u003ccode\u003eModel.to_yaml()\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003ekeras.models.model_from_yaml\u003c/code\u003e have\nbeen replaced to raise a \u003ccode\u003eRuntimeError\u003c/code\u003e as they can be abused to cause\narbitrary code execution. It is recommended to use JSON serialization\ninstead of YAML, or, a better alternative, serialize to H5.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" \u003ccode\u003etf.while_loop\u003c/code\u003e, which caused it to execute\nsequentially, even when \u003ccode\u003eparallel_iterations\u0026gt;1\u003c/code\u003e, has now been fixed.\nHowever, the increased parallelism may result in increased memory use.\nUsers who experience unwanted regressions should reset their\n\u003ccode\u003ewhile_loop\u003c/code\u003e's \u003ccode\u003eparallel_iterations\u003c/code\u003e value to 1, which is consistent\nwith prior behavior.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eKeras has been split into a separate PIP package (\u003ccode\u003ekeras\u003c/code\u003e), and its code\nhas been moved to the GitHub repository\n\u003ca href=\"http://github.com/keras-team/keras\"\u003ekeras-team/keras\u003c/a\u003e. The API\nendpoints for \u003ccode\u003etf.keras\u003c/code\u003e stay unchanged, but are now backed by the\n\u003ccode\u003ekeras\u003c/code\u003e PIP package. All Keras-related PRs and issues should now be\ndirected to the GitHub repository.\n\u003ca href=\"http://github.com/keras-team/keras\"\u003ekeras-team/keras\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.utils.experimental.DatasetCreator\u003c/code\u003e now takes an optional\n\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.InputOptions\u003c/code\u003e for specific options when used with\ndistribution.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.experimental.SidecarEvaluator\u003c/code\u003e is now available for a program\nintended to be run on an evaluator task, which is commonly used to\nsupplement a training cluster running with\n\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.experimental.ParameterServerStrategy\u003c/code\u003e (see\n`\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/tutorials/distribute/parameter_server_training\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ehttps://www.tensorflow.org/tutorials/distribute/parameter_server_training\u003c/a\u003e).\nIt can also be used with single-worker training or other strategies. See\ndocstring for more info.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePreprocessing layers moved from experimental to core.\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eImport paths moved from \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.layers.preprocessing.experimental\u003c/code\u003e\nto \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.layers\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUpdates to Preprocessing layers API for consistency and clarity:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eStringLookup\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eIntegerLookup\u003c/code\u003e default for \u003ccode\u003emask_token\u003c/code\u003e changed\nto \u003ccode\u003eNone\u003c/code\u003e. This matches the default masking behavior of \u003ccode\u003eHashing\u003c/code\u003e\nand \u003ccode\u003eEmbedding\u003c/code\u003e layers. To keep existing behavior, pass\n\u003ccode\u003emask_token=\"\"\u003c/code\u003e during layer creation.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRenamed \u003ccode\u003e\"binary\"\u003c/code\u003e output mode to \u003ccode\u003e\"multi_hot\"\u003c/code\u003e for\n\u003ccode\u003eCategoryEncoding\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eStringLookup\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eIntegerLookup\u003c/code\u003e, and\n\u003ccode\u003eTextVectorization\u003c/code\u003e. Multi-hot encoding will no longer automatically\nuprank rank 1 inputs, so these layers can now multi-hot encode\nunbatched multi-dimensional samples.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded a new output mode \u003ccode\u003e\"one_hot\"\u003c/code\u003e for \u003ccode\u003eCategoryEncoding\u003c/code\u003e,\n\u003ccode\u003eStringLookup\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eIntegerLookup\u003c/code\u003e, which will encode each element in\nan input batch individually, and automatically append a new output\ndimension if necessary. Use this mode on rank 1 inputs for the old\n\u003ccode\u003e\"binary\"\u003c/code\u003e behavior of one-hot encoding a batch of scalars.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eNormalization\u003c/code\u003e will no longer automatically uprank rank 1 inputs,\nallowing normalization of unbatched multi-dimensional samples.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.lite\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe recommended Android NDK version for building TensorFlow Lite has\nbeen changed from r18b to r19c.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSupports int64 for mul.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSupports native variable builtin ops - ReadVariable, AssignVariable.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eConverter:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eExperimental support for variables in TFLite. To enable through\nconversion, users need to set\n\u003ccode\u003eexperimental_enable_resource_variables\u003c/code\u003e on tf.lite.TFLiteConverter\nto True. Note: mutable variables is only available using\n\u003ccode\u003efrom_saved_model\u003c/code\u003e in this release, support for other methods is\ncoming soon.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOld Converter (TOCO) is getting removed from next release. It's been\ndeprecated for few releases already.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.saved_model\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSavedModels can now save custom gradients. Use the option\n\u003ccode\u003etf.saved_model.SaveOption(experimental_custom_gradients=True)\u003c/code\u003e to\nenable this feature. The documentation in\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/guide/advanced_autodiff#custom_gradients\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eAdvanced autodiff\u003c/a\u003e\nhas been updated.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eObject metadata has now been deprecated and no longer saved to the\nSavedModel.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTF Core:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etf.config.experimental.reset_memory_stats\u003c/code\u003e to reset the tracked\npeak memory returned by \u003ccode\u003etf.config.experimental.get_memory_info\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etarget_workers\u003c/code\u003e param to \u003ccode\u003edata_service_ops.from_dataset_id\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003edata_service_ops.distribute\u003c/code\u003e. Users can specify \u003ccode\u003e\"AUTO\"\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003e\"ANY\"\u003c/code\u003e, or\n\u003ccode\u003e\"LOCAL\"\u003c/code\u003e (case insensitive). If \u003ccode\u003e\"AUTO\"\u003c/code\u003e, tf.data service runtime\ndecides which workers to read from. If \u003ccode\u003e\"ANY\"\u003c/code\u003e, TF workers read from any\ntf.data service workers. If \u003ccode\u003e\"LOCAL\"\u003c/code\u003e, TF workers will only read from\nlocal in-processs tf.data service workers. \u003ccode\u003e\"AUTO\"\u003c/code\u003e works well for most\ncases, while users can specify other targets. For example, \u003ccode\u003e\"LOCAL\"\u003c/code\u003e\nwould help avoid RPCs and data copy if every TF worker colocates with a\ntf.data service worker. Currently, \u003ccode\u003e\"AUTO\"\u003c/code\u003e reads from any tf.data\nservice workers to preserve existing behavior. The default value is\n\u003ccode\u003e\"AUTO\"\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-bug-fixes-and-other-changes-14\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" href=\"#bug-fixes-and-other-changes-14\"\u003eBug Fixes and Other Changes\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTF Core:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etf.lookup.experimental.MutableHashTable\u003c/code\u003e, which provides a\ngeneric mutable hash table implementation.\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCompared to \u003ccode\u003etf.lookup.experimental.DenseHashTable\u003c/code\u003e this offers\nlower overall memory usage, and a cleaner API. It does not require\nspecifying a \u003ccode\u003edelete_key\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eempty_key\u003c/code\u003e that cannot be inserted\ninto the table.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded support for specifying number of subdivisions in all reduce host\ncollective. This parallelizes work on CPU and speeds up the collective\nperformance. Default behavior is unchanged.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd an option \u003ccode\u003eperturb_singular\u003c/code\u003e to \u003ccode\u003etf.linalg.tridiagonal_solve\u003c/code\u003e that\nallows solving linear systems with a numerically singular tridiagonal\nmatrix, e.g. for use in inverse iteration.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etf.linalg.eigh_tridiagonal\u003c/code\u003e that computes the eigenvalues of a\nHermitian tridiagonal matrix.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.constant\u003c/code\u003e now places its output on the current default device.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSavedModel\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etf.saved_model.experimental.TrackableResource\u003c/code\u003e, which allows\nthe creation of custom wrapper objects for resource tensors.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded a SavedModel load option to allow restoring partial\ncheckpoints into the SavedModel. See\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/saved_model/LoadOptions\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.saved_model.LoadOptions\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\nfor details.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded a new op \u003ccode\u003eSparseSegmentSumGrad\u003c/code\u003e to match the other sparse segment\ngradient ops and avoid an extra gather operation that was in the\nprevious gradient implementation.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded a new session config setting \u003ccode\u003einternal_fragmentation_fraction\u003c/code\u003e,\nwhich controls when the BFC Allocator needs to split an oversized chunk\nto satisfy an allocation request.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etf.get_current_name_scope()\u003c/code\u003e which returns the current full name\nscope string that will be prepended to op names.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePromoting \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.bucket_by_sequence_length\u003c/code\u003e API to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.bucket_by_sequence_length\u003c/code\u003e and deprecating the\nexperimental endpoint.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePromoting \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.get_single_element\u003c/code\u003e API to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.get_single_element\u003c/code\u003e and deprecating the experimental\nendpoint.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePromoting \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.group_by_window\u003c/code\u003e API to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.group_by_window\u003c/code\u003e and deprecating the experimental\nendpoint.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePromoting \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.RandomDataset\u003c/code\u003e API to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.random\u003c/code\u003e and deprecating the experimental endpoint.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePromoting \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.scan\u003c/code\u003e API to \u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.scan\u003c/code\u003e and\ndeprecating the experimental endpoint.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePromoting \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.snapshot\u003c/code\u003e API to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.shapshot\u003c/code\u003e and deprecating the experimental endpoint.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePromoting \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.take_while\u003c/code\u003e API to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.take_while\u003c/code\u003e and deprecating the experimental endpoint.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePromoting \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.ThreadingOptions\u003c/code\u003e API to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.data.ThreadingOptions\u003c/code\u003e and deprecating the experimental endpoint.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePromoting \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.unique\u003c/code\u003e API to \u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.unique\u003c/code\u003e\nand deprecating the experimental endpoint.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003estop_on_empty_dataset\u003c/code\u003e parameter to \u003ccode\u003esample_from_datasets\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003echoose_from_datasets\u003c/code\u003e. Setting \u003ccode\u003estop_on_empty_dataset=True\u003c/code\u003e will stop\nsampling if it encounters an empty dataset. This preserves the sampling\nratio throughout training. The prior behavior was to continue sampling,\nskipping over exhausted datasets, until all datasets are exhausted. By\ndefault, the original behavior (\u003ccode\u003estop_on_empty_dataset=False\u003c/code\u003e) is\npreserved.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRemoved previously deprecated tf.data statistics related APIs:\n\u003cul objects.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd \u003ccode\u003ekeepdims\u003c/code\u003e argument to all \u003ccode\u003eGlobalPooling\u003c/code\u003e layers.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd \u003ccode\u003einclude_preprocessing\u003c/code\u003e argument to \u003ccode\u003eMobileNetV3\u003c/code\u003e architectures to\ncontrol the inclusion of \u003ccode\u003eRescaling\u003c/code\u003e the cached function and generate a new one. This is\nuseful to regenerate in a single call the compiled training function\nwhen any \u003ccode\u003e.trainable\u003c/code\u003e attribute of any model's layer has changed.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eModels now have a \u003ccode\u003esave_spec\u003c/code\u003e property which contains the \u003ccode\u003eTensorSpec\u003c/code\u003e\nspecs for calling the model.
