dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSupport for Python3.9 has been added.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e service now supports strict round-robin reads, which is useful\nfor synchronous training workloads where example sizes vary. With strict\nround robin reads, users can guarantee that consumers get similar-sized\nexamples in the same step.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003etf.data service now supports optional compression. Previously data would\nalways be compressed, but now you can disable compression by passing\n\u003ccode\u003ecompression=None\u003c/code\u003e to \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.service.distribute(...)\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.batch()\u003c/code\u003e now supports \u003ccode\u003enum_parallel_calls\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003edeterministic\u003c/code\u003e arguments. \u003ccode\u003enum_parallel_calls\u003c/code\u003e is used to indicate that\nmultiple input batches should be computed in parallel. With\n\u003ccode\u003enum_parallel_calls\u003c/code\u003e set, \u003ccode\u003edeterministic\u003c/code\u003e is used to indicate that\noutputs can be obtained in the non-deterministic order.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOptions returned by \u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.options()\u003c/code\u003e are no longer mutable.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003etf.data input pipelines can now be executed in debug mode, which\ndisables any asynchrony, parallelism, or non-determinism and forces\nPython execution (as opposed to trace-compiled graph execution) of\nuser-defined functions passed into transformations such as \u003ccode\u003emap\u003c/code\u003e. The\ndebug mode can be enabled through\n\u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.enable_debug_mode()\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.lite\u003c/code\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEnabled the new MLIR-based quantization backend by default\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe new backend is used for 8 bits full integer post-training\nquantization\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe new backend removes the redundant rescales and fixes some bugs\n(shared weight/bias, extremely small scales, etc)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSet \u003ccode\u003eexperimental_new_quantizer\u003c/code\u003e in tf.lite.TFLiteConverter to False\nto disable this change\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras\u003c/code\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.metrics.AUC\u003c/code\u003e now support logit predictions.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEnabled a new supported input type in \u003ccode\u003eModel.fit\u003c/code\u003e,\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.utils.experimental.DatasetCreator\u003c/code\u003e, which takes a callable,\n\u003ccode\u003edataset_fn\u003c/code\u003e. \u003ccode\u003eDatasetCreator\u003c/code\u003e is intended to work across all\n\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute\u003c/code\u003e strategies, and is the only input type supported for\nParameter Server strategy.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute\u003c/code\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.experimental.ParameterServerStrategy\u003c/code\u003e now supports\ntraining with Keras \u003ccode\u003eModel.fit\u003c/code\u003e when used with \u003ccode\u003eDatasetCreator\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCreating \u003ccode\u003etf.random.Generator\u003c/code\u003e under \u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.Strategy\u003c/code\u003e scopes is\nnow allowed (except for\n\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.experimental.CentralStorageStrategy\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.experimental.ParameterServerStrategy\u003c/code\u003e). Different\nreplicas will get different random-number streams.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTPU embedding support\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003eprofile_data_directory\u003c/code\u003e to \u003ccode\u003eEmbeddingConfigSpec\u003c/code\u003e in\n\u003ccode\u003e_tpu_estimator_embedding.py\u003c/code\u003e. This allows embedding lookup statistics\ngathered at runtime to be used in embedding layer partitioning\ndecisions.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePluggableDevice\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThird-party devices can now connect to TensorFlow as plug-ins through\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/community/blob/master/rfcs/20200612-stream-executor-c-api.md\"\u003eStreamExecutor C API\u003c/a\u003e.\nand\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/community/blob/master/rfcs/20200624-pluggable-device-for-tensorflow.md\"\u003ePluggableDevice\u003c/a\u003e\ninterface.\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd custom ops and kernels through\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/community/blob/master/rfcs/20190814-kernel-and-op-registration.md\"\u003ekernel and op registration C API\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRegister custom graph optimization passes with\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/community/blob/master/rfcs/20201027-modular-tensorflow-graph-c-api.md\"\u003egraph optimization C API\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/oneapi-src/oneDNN\"\u003eoneAPI Deep Neural Network Library (oneDNN)\u003c/a\u003e\nCPU performance optimizations from\n\u003ca href=\"https://software.intel.com/content/www/us/en/develop/articles/intel-optimization-for-tensorflow-installation-guide.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eIntel-optimized TensorFlow\u003c/a\u003e\nare now available in the official x86-64 Linux and Windows builds.\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThey are off by default. Enable them by setting the environment variable\n\u003ccode\u003eTF_ENABLE_ONEDNN_OPTS=1\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWe do not recommend using them in GPU systems, as they have not been\nsufficiently tested with GPUs yet.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTensorFlow pip packages are now built with CUDA11.2 and cuDNN dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePreprocessing layers API consistency changes:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eStringLookup\u003c/code\u003e added \u003ccode\u003eoutput_mode\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003esparse\u003c/code\u003e, and\n\u003ccode\u003epad_to_max_tokens\u003c/code\u003e arguments with same semantics as\n\u003ccode\u003eTextVectorization\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eIntegerLookup\u003c/code\u003e added \u003ccode\u003eoutput_mode\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003esparse\u003c/code\u003e, and\n\u003ccode\u003epad_to_max_tokens\u003c/code\u003e arguments with same semantics as\n\u003ccode\u003eTextVectorization\u003c/code\u003e. Renamed \u003ccode\u003emax_values\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eoov_value\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003emask_value\u003c/code\u003e to \u003ccode\u003emax_tokens\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eoov_token\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003emask_token\u003c/code\u003e to align\nwith \u003ccode\u003eStringLookup\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eTextVectorization\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eTextVectorization\u003c/code\u003e default for \u003ccode\u003epad_to_max_tokens\u003c/code\u003e switched to\nFalse.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eCategoryEncoding\u003c/code\u003e no longer supports \u003ccode\u003eadapt\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eIntegerLookup\u003c/code\u003e now\nsupports equivalent functionality. \u003ccode\u003emax_tokens\u003c/code\u003e argument renamed to\n\u003ccode\u003enum_tokens\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eDiscretization\u003c/code\u003e added \u003ccode\u003enum_bins\u003c/code\u003e argument for learning bins\nboundaries through calling \u003ccode\u003eadapt\u003c/code\u003e on a dataset. Renamed \u003ccode\u003ebins\u003c/code\u003e\nargument to \u003ccode\u003ebin_boundaries\u003c/code\u003e for specifying bins without \u003ccode\u003eadapt\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eImprovements to model saving/loading:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003emodel.load_weights\u003c/code\u003e now accepts paths to saved models.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eKeras inputs can now be created directly from arbitrary \u003ccode\u003etf.TypeSpecs\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTwo new learning rate schedules added:\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.schedules.CosineDecay\u003c/code\u003e\nand\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.optimizers.schedules.CosineDecayRestarts\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eExposing \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.ExternalStatePolicy\u003c/code\u003e, which can be used\nto control how external state should be handled during dataset\nserialization or iterator checkpointing.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eChanging \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.save\u003c/code\u003e to store the type specification of\nthe dataset elements. This avoids the need for explicitly specifying the\n\u003ccode\u003eelement_spec\u003c/code\u003e argument of \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.load\u003c/code\u003e when loading the\npreviously saved dataset.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd \u003ccode\u003e.element_spec\u003c/code\u003e property to \u003ccode\u003etf.data.DatasetSpec\u003c/code\u003e to access the\ninner spec. This can be used to extract the structure of nested\ndatasets.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.AutoShardingPolicy.HINT\u003c/code\u003e which can be used to\nprovide hints to tf.distribute-based auto-sharding as to where in the\ninput pipeline to insert sharding transformations.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMake tf.data.Options persistent across \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eGraphDef\u003c/code\u003e\nboundaries.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eXLA compilation:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.function(experimental_compile=True)\u003c/code\u003e has become a stable API,\nrenamed \u003ccode\u003etf.function(jit_compile=True)\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eXLA can now compile MirroredStrategy: the step function passed\nto\u003ccode\u003estrategy.run\u003c/code\u003e can now be annoted with \u003ccode\u003ejit_compile=True\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRename \u003ccode\u003eexperimental_prefetch_to_device\u003c/code\u003e in \u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.InputOptions\u003c/code\u003e\nto \u003ccode\u003eexperimental_fetch_to_device\u003c/code\u003e to better reflect the purpose.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.lite\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eclass \u003ccode\u003etflite::Subgraph\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRemoved the \u003ccode\u003etensors()\u003c/code\u003e method and the non-const overload of the\n\u003ccode\u003enodes_and_registration()\u003c/code\u003e method, both of which were previously\ndocumented as temporary and to be removed.\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUses of \u003ccode\u003etensors()\u003c/code\u003e can be replaced by calling the existing\nmethods \u003ccode\u003etensors_size()\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003etensor(int)\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUses of the non-const overload of \u003ccode\u003enodes_and_registration\u003c/code\u003e can\nbe replaced by calling the existing methods \u003ccode\u003enodes_size()\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003econtext()\u003c/code\u003e, and then calling the \u003ccode\u003eGetNodeAndRegistration\u003c/code\u003e\nmethod in the \u003ccode\u003eTfLiteContext\u003c/code\u003e returned by \u003ccode\u003econtext()\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNNAPI\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRemoved deprecated \u003ccode\u003eInterpreter::UseNNAPI(bool)\u003c/code\u003e C++ API.\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUse \u003ccode\u003eNnApiDelegate()\u003c/code\u003e and related delegate configuration methods\ndirectly.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eReplaced the model cache key for models computation algorithm with\none guaranteed to be stable across runs.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e16 bits quantization\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded int16x8 support for ABS, REDUCE_MAX and REDUCE_MIN operators.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdditional tests and fixes for ADD and SUB operators.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded support for saved model's session initializer through\n\u003ccode\u003eTFLiteConverter.from_saved_model\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded DEPTH_TO_SPACE support in Post training quantization.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded dynamic range quantization support for the BatchMatMul op.\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBoth symmetric and asymmetric quantized input tensor are supported.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd \u003ccode\u003eRFFT2D\u003c/code\u003e as builtin op. (\u003ccode\u003eRFFT2D\u003c/code\u003e also supports \u003ccode\u003eRFFTD\u003c/code\u003e.) Currently\nonly supports float32 input.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd 5D support to \u003ccode\u003eSLICE\u003c/code\u003e op.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTFLite Supports SingatureDef:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTFLiteConverter exports models with SignatureDef\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eInterpreter supports getting a list of signatures and getting\ncallable function for a given signaturedef.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd int8 support for \u003ccode\u003eReshapeV2\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd experimental support for optimization with sparsity.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd nominal support for unsigned 32-bit integer tensor types. Note that\nvery few TFLite kernels support this type natively, so its use in mobile\nML authoring is generally discouraged.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd support for static hash tables through\n\u003ccode\u003eTFLiteConverter.from_saved_model\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe Python TF Lite Interpreter bindings now has an option\n\u003ccode\u003eexperimental_preserve_all_tensors\u003c/code\u003e to aid in debugging conversion.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eQuantized x86 execution defaults to Ruy GEMM library for platforms with\nAVX support.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDeprecate\n\u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v1.lite.experimental.get_potentially_supported_ops\u003c/code\u003e. Use\n\u003ccode\u003etf.lite.TFLiteConverter\u003c/code\u003e directly to check whether a model is\nconvertible.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd support to select one of three different built-in op resolvers\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEnabled post training with calibrations for models that require user\nprovided TensorFlow Lite custom op libraries via\n\u003ccode\u003econverter.target_spec._experimental_custom_op_registerers\u003c/code\u003e. used in\nPython Interpreter API.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTF Core:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCorrected higher-order gradients of control flow constructs (\u003ccode\u003etf.cond\u003c/code\u003e,\n\u003ccode\u003etf.while_loop\u003c/code\u003e, and compositions like \u003ccode\u003etf.foldl\u003c/code\u003e) computed with\n\u003ccode\u003etf.GradientTape\u003c/code\u003e inside a \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eChanged the default step size in \u003ccode\u003egradient_checker_v2.compute_gradients\u003c/code\u003e\nto be exactly representable as a binary floating point numbers. This\navoids poluting gradient approximations needlessly, which is some cases\nleads to false negatives in op gradient tests.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etf.config.experimental.get_memory_info\u003c/code\u003e, returning a dict with\nthe current and peak memory usage. Deprecated\n\u003ccode\u003etf.config.experimental.get_memory_usage\u003c/code\u003e in favor of this new function.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eExtended \u003ccode\u003etf.config.experimental.enable_tensor_float_32_execution\u003c/code\u003e to\ncontrol Tensor-Float-32 evaluation in RNNs.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded a 'experimental_payloads' field to tf.errors.OpError and its\nsubclasses to support more detailed error reporting. This is inspired\nfrom Abseil Status payloads:\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/abseil/abseil-cpp/blob/master/absl/status/status.h\"\u003ehttps://github.com/abseil/abseil-cpp/blob/master/absl/status/status.h\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.summary\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNew \u003ccode\u003etf.summary.graph\u003c/code\u003e allows manual write of TensorFlow graph\n(\u003ccode\u003etf.Graph\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v1.GraphDef\u003c/code\u003e) as a summary. This is not a\nreplacement for the trace-based API.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSet \u003ccode\u003e/d2ReducedOptimizeHugeFunctions\u003c/code\u003e by default for Windows builds. This\nprovides a big compile-time speedup, and effectively raises the minimum\nsupported MSVC version to 16.4 (current: 16.8).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSee:\n\u003ca href=\"https://groups.google.com/a/tensorflow.org/d/topic/build/SsW98Eo7l3o/discussion\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ehttps://groups.google.com/a/tensorflow.org/d/topic/build/SsW98Eo7l3o/discussion\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTensorRT\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRemoved the deprecated \u003ccode\u003esession_config\u003c/code\u003e parameter for the TF1-TRT\nconverter \u003ccode\u003eTrtGraphConverter\u003c/code\u003e. Previously, we issued a warning when the\nvalue of the parameter is not None.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe TF2-TRT converter \u003ccode\u003eTrtGraphConverterV2\u003c/code\u003e takes an object of class\nTrtConversionParams as a parameter. Removed three deprecated fields from\nthis class: \u003ccode\u003erewriter_config_template\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eis_dynamic_op\u003c/code\u003e, and\n\u003ccode\u003emax_batch_size\u003c/code\u003e. Previously, we issued a warning when the value of\n\u003ccode\u003erewriter_config_template\u003c/code\u003e is not None. We issued an error when the\nvalue of \u003ccode\u003eis_dynamic_op\u003c/code\u003e is not True. We didn't use the value for\n\u003ccode\u003emax_batch_size\u003c/code\u003e for building TensorRT engines. Add parameters\n\u003ccode\u003euse_dynamic_shape\u003c/code\u003e to enable dynamic shape support. The default is to\ndisable dynamic shape support. Add \u003ccode\u003edynamic_shape_profile_strategy\u003c/code\u003e for\nselecting a dynamic shape profile strategy. The default is profile\nstrategy is \u003ccode\u003eRange\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIssue a warning when function get_tensorrt_rewriter_config is used.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTF XLA\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd new enum value \u003ccode\u003eMLIR_BRIDGE_ROLLOUT_SAFE_MODE_ENABLED\u003c/code\u003e to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.config.experimental.mlir_bridge_rollout\u003c/code\u003e to enable a \"safe\" mode.\nThis runs the MLIR bridge only when an analysis of the graph only when\nan analysis of the graph determines that it is safe to run.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd new enum value \u003ccode\u003eMLIR_BRIDGE_ROLLOUT_SAFE_MODE_FALLBACK_ENABLED' to\u003c/code\u003etf.config.experimental.mlir_bridge_rollout` to enable a fallback for\nthe MLIR bridge in a \"safe\" mode. This runs the MLIR bridge in a\nFallbackEnabled mode when an analysis of the graph determines that the\ngraph does not have unsupported features.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eDeterministic Op Functionality:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd determinism-unimplemented exception-throwing to the segment-sum ops.\nWhen the environment variable \u003ccode\u003eTF_DETERMINISTIC_OPS\u003c/code\u003e is set to \u003ccode\u003e\"true\"\u003c/code\u003e\nor \u003ccode\u003e\"1\"\u003c/code\u003e (when op-determinism is expected), an attempt to run the\nfollowing ops on a GPU will throw \u003ccode\u003etf.errors.UnimplementedError\u003c/code\u003e (with\nan understandable message) when \u003ccode\u003edata\u003c/code\u003e is a floating-point type,\nincluding complex types (if supported): \u003ccode\u003etf.math.segment_prod\u003c/code\u003e,\n\u003ccode\u003etf.math.segment_sum\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003etf.math.unsorted_segment_mean\u003c/code\u003e,\n\u003ccode\u003etf.math.unsorted_segment_sqrt_n\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003etf.math.unsorted_segment_prod\u003c/code\u003e,\n\u003ccode\u003etf.math.unsorted_segment_sum\u003c/code\u003e, and therefore also\n\u003ccode\u003etf.convert_to_tensor\u003c/code\u003e when \u003ccode\u003evalue\u003c/code\u003e is of type \u003ccode\u003etf.IndexedSlices\u003c/code\u003e (such\nas in the back prop though \u003ccode\u003etf.gather\u003c/code\u003e into a dense embedding). See\nissue \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/39751\" data-hovercard-type=\"issue\" data-hovercard-url=\"/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/39751/hovercard\"\u003e39751\u003c/a\u003e\nwhich this change addresses, but does not solve. This exception-throwing\nbehavior can be disabled by setting the environment variable\n\u003ccode\u003eTF_DISABLE_SEGMENT_REDUCTION_OP_DETERMINISM_EXCEPTIONS\u003c/code\u003e to \u003ccode\u003e\"true\"\u003c/code\u003e or\n\u003ccode\u003e\"1\"\u003c/code\u003e. For more information about these changes, see the description in\npull request\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/pull/47772\" data-hovercard-type=\"pull_request\" data-hovercard-url=\"/tensorflow/tensorflow/pull/47772/hovercard\"\u003e47772\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIn previous versions of TensorFlow, when a GPU was available,\n\u003ccode\u003etf.sparse.sparse_dense_matmul\u003c/code\u003e introduced truly random noise in the\nforward path for data of type \u003ccode\u003etf.float32\u003c/code\u003e but not for data of type\n\u003ccode\u003etf.float64\u003c/code\u003e (for which there was no GPU implementation). In this\ncurrent release, GPU support for other floating-point types\n(\u003ccode\u003etf.float16\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003etf.float64\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003etf.complex64\u003c/code\u003e, and \u003ccode\u003etf.complex128\u003c/code\u003e) has\nbeen added for this op. If you were relying on the determinism of the\n\u003ccode\u003etf.float64\u003c/code\u003e CPU implementation being automatically selected because of\nthe absence of the \u003ccode\u003etf.float64\u003c/code\u003e GPU implementation, you with either need\nto force the op to run on the CPU or use a different data dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute\u003c/code\u003e introduces experimental support for asynchronous training of\nmodels via the\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/distribute/experimental/ParameterServerStrategy\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.experimental.ParameterServerStrategy\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\nAPI. Please see the\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/tutorials/distribute/parameter_server_training\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003etutorial\u003c/a\u003e\nto learn more.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/distribute/MultiWorkerMirroredStrategy\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eMultiWorkerMirroredStrategy\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\nis now a stable API and is no longer considered experimental. Some of the\nmajor improvements involve handling peer failure and many bug fixes. Please\ncheck out the detailed tutorial on\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/tutorials/distribute/multi_worker_with_keras\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eMulti-worker training with Keras\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIntroduces experimental support for a new module named\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/experimental/numpy\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.experimental.numpy\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\nwhich is a NumPy-compatible API for writing TF programs. See the\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/guide/tf_numpy\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003edetailed guide\u003c/a\u003e to learn more.\nAdditional details below.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAdds Support for\n\u003ca href=\"https://blogs.nvidia.com/blog/2020/05/14/tensorfloat-32-precision-format/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eTensorFloat-32\u003c/a\u003e\non Ampere based GPUs. TensorFloat-32, or TF32 for short, is a math mode for\nNVIDIA Ampere based GPUs and is enabled by default.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eA major refactoring of the internals of the Keras Functional API has been\ncompleted, that should improve the reliability, stability, and performance\nof constructing Functional models.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eKeras mixed precision API\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/keras/mixed_precision?version=nightly\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\nis no longer experimental and allows the use of 16-bit floating point\nformats during training, improving performance by up to 3x on GPUs and 60%\non TPUs. Please see below for additional details.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTensorFlow Profiler now supports profiling \u003ccode\u003eMultiWorkerMirroredStrategy\u003c/code\u003e and\ntracing multiple workers using the\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/guide/profiler#profiling_apis\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003esampling mode API\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTFLite Profiler for Android is available. See the detailed\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/lite/performance/measurement#trace_tensorflow_lite_internals_in_android\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eguide\u003c/a\u003e\nto learn more.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTensorFlow pip packages are now built with CUDA11 and cuDNN 8.0.2.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-breaking-changes-15\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" href=\"#breaking-changes-15\"\u003eBreaking Changes\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTF Core:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCertain float32 ops run in lower precision on Ampere based GPUs,\nincluding matmuls and convolutions, due to the use of\n\u003ca href=\"https://blogs.nvidia.com/blog/2020/05/14/tensorfloat-32-precision-format/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eTensorFloat-32\u003c/a\u003e.\nSpecifically, inputs to such ops are rounded from 23 bits of precision\nto 10 bits of precision. This is unlikely to cause issues in practice\nfor deep learning models. In some cases, TensorFloat-32 is also used for\ncomplex64 ops. TensorFloat-32 can be disabled by running\n\u003ccode\u003etf.config.experimental.enable_tensor_float_32_execution(False)\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe byte layout for string tensors across the C-API has been updated to\nmatch TF Core/C++; i.e., a contiguous array of\n\u003ccode\u003etensorflow::tstring\u003c/code\u003e/\u003ccode\u003eTF_TString\u003c/code\u003es.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eC-API functions \u003ccode\u003eTF_StringDecode\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eTF_StringEncode\u003c/code\u003e, and\n\u003ccode\u003eTF_StringEncodedSize\u003c/code\u003e are no longer relevant and have been removed; see\n\u003ccode\u003ecore/platform/ctstring.h\u003c/code\u003e for string access/modification in C.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etensorflow.python\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003etensorflow.core\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003etensorflow.compiler\u003c/code\u003e modules\nare now hidden. These modules are not part of TensorFlow public API.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.raw_ops.Max\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003etf.raw_ops.Min\u003c/code\u003e no longer accept inputs of type\n\u003ccode\u003etf.complex64\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003etf.complex128\u003c/code\u003e, because the behavior of these ops is\nnot well defined for complex types.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eXLA:CPU and XLA:GPU devices are no longer registered by default. Use\n\u003ccode\u003eTF_XLA_FLAGS=--tf_xla_enable_xla_devices\u003c/code\u003e if you really need them, but\nthis flag will eventually be removed in subsequent releases.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe \u003ccode\u003esteps_per_execution\u003c/code\u003e argument in \u003ccode\u003emodel.compile()\u003c/code\u003e is no longer\nexperimental; if you were passing \u003ccode\u003eexperimental_steps_per_execution\u003c/code\u003e,\nrename it to \u003ccode\u003esteps_per_execution\u003c/code\u003e in your code. This argument controls\nthe number of batches to run during each \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e call when calling\n\u003ccode\u003emodel.fit()\u003c/code\u003e. Running multiple batches inside a single \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e\ncall can greatly improve performance on TPUs or small models with a\nlarge Python overhead.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eA \u003cstrong\u003emajor refactoring\u003c/strong\u003e of the internals of the Keras Functional API may\naffect code that is relying on certain internal details:\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCode that uses \u003ccode\u003eisinstance(x, tf.Tensor)\u003c/code\u003e instead of \u003ccode\u003etf.is_tensor\u003c/code\u003e when\nchecking Keras symbolic inputs/outputs should switch to using\n\u003ccode\u003etf.is_tensor\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCode that is overly dependent on the exact names attached to symbolic\ntensors (e.g. assumes there will be \":0\" at the end of the inputs,\ntreats names as unique identifiers instead of using \u003ccode\u003etensor.ref()\u003c/code\u003e,\netc.) may break.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCode that uses full path for \u003ccode\u003eget_concrete_function\u003c/code\u003e to trace Keras\nsymbolic inputs directly should switch to building matching\n\u003ccode\u003etf.TensorSpec\u003c/code\u003es directly and tracing the \u003ccode\u003eTensorSpec\u003c/code\u003e objects.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCode that relies on the exact number and names of the op layers that\nTensorFlow operations were converted into may have changed.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCode that uses \u003ccode\u003etf.map_fn\u003c/code\u003e/\u003ccode\u003etf.cond\u003c/code\u003e/\u003ccode\u003etf.while_loop\u003c/code\u003e/control flow as op\nlayers and happens to work before TF 2.4. These will explicitly be\nunsupported now. Converting these ops to Functional API op layers was\nunreliable before TF 2.4, and prone to erroring incomprehensibly or\nbeing silently buggy.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCode that directly asserts on a Keras symbolic value in cases where ops\nlike \u003ccode\u003etf.rank\u003c/code\u003e used to return a static or symbolic value depending on if\nthe input had a fully static shape or not. Now these ops always return\nsymbolic values.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCode already susceptible to leaking tensors outside of graphs becomes\nslightly more likely to do so now.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCode that tries directly getting gradients with respect to symbolic\nKeras inputs/outputs. Use \u003ccode\u003eGradientTape\u003c/code\u003e on the actual Tensors passed to\nthe already-constructed model instead.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCode that requires very tricky shape manipulation via converted op\nlayers in order to work, where the Keras symbolic shape inference proves\ninsufficient.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCode that tries manually walking a \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.Model\u003c/code\u003e layer by layer and\nassumes layers only ever have one positional argument. This assumption\ndoesn't hold true before TF 2.4 either, but is more likely to cause\nissues now.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCode that manually enters \u003ccode\u003ekeras.backend.get_graph()\u003c/code\u003e before building a\nfunctional model is no longer needed.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eStart enforcing input shape assumptions when calling Functional API\nKeras models. This may potentially break some users, in case there is a\nmismatch between the shape used when creating \u003ccode\u003eInput\u003c/code\u003e objects in a\nFunctional model, and the shape of the data passed to that model. You\ncan fix this mismatch by either calling the model with correctly-shaped\ndata, or by relaxing \u003ccode\u003eInput\u003c/code\u003e shape assumptions (note that you can pass\nshapes with \u003ccode\u003eNone\u003c/code\u003e entries for axes that are meant to be dynamic). You\ncan also disable the input checking entirely by setting\n\u003ccode\u003emodel.input_spec = None\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSeveral changes have been made to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision.experimental\u003c/code\u003e. Note that it is now recommended\nto use the non-experimental \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision\u003c/code\u003e API.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eAutoCastVariable.dtype\u003c/code\u003e now refers to the actual variable dtype, not\nthe dtype it will be casted to.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhen mixed precision is enabled, \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.layers.Embedding\u003c/code\u003e now outputs\na float16 or bfloat16 tensor instead of a float32 tensor.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe property\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision.experimental.LossScaleOptimizer.loss_scale\u003c/code\u003e is\nnow a tensor, not a \u003ccode\u003eLossScale\u003c/code\u003e object. This means to get a loss scale\nof a \u003ccode\u003eLossScaleOptimizer\u003c/code\u003e as a tensor, you must now call\n\u003ccode\u003eopt.loss_scale\u003c/code\u003einstead of \u003ccode\u003eopt.loss_scale()\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe property \u003ccode\u003eshould_cast_variables\u003c/code\u003e has been removed from\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision.experimental.Policy\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhen passing a \u003ccode\u003etf.mixed_precision.experimental.DynamicLossScale\u003c/code\u003e to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision.experimental.LossScaleOptimizer\u003c/code\u003e, the\n\u003ccode\u003eDynamicLossScale\u003c/code\u003e's multiplier must be 2.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhen passing a \u003ccode\u003etf.mixed_precision.experimental.DynamicLossScale\u003c/code\u003e to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision.experimental.LossScaleOptimizer\u003c/code\u003e, the weights\nof the \u003ccode\u003eDynanmicLossScale\u003c/code\u003e are copied into the \u003ccode\u003eLossScaleOptimizer\u003c/code\u003e\ninstead of being reused. This means modifying the weights of the\n\u003ccode\u003eDynamicLossScale\u003c/code\u003e will no longer affect the weights of the\nLossScaleOptimizer, and vice versa.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe global policy can no longer be set to a non-floating point policy in\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision.experimental.set_policy\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIn \u003ccode\u003eLayer.call\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eAutoCastVariable\u003c/code\u003es will no longer be casted within\n\u003ccode\u003eMirroredStrategy.run\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003eReplicaContext.merge_call\u003c/code\u003e. This is because a\nthread local variable is used to determine whether \u003ccode\u003eAutoCastVariable\u003c/code\u003es\nare casted, and those two functions run with a different thread. Note\nthis only applies if one of these two functions is called within\n\u003ccode\u003eLayer.call\u003c/code\u003e; if one of those two functions calls \u003ccode\u003eLayer.call\u003c/code\u003e,\n\u003ccode\u003eAutoCastVariable\u003c/code\u003es will still be casted.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.service.DispatchServer\u003c/code\u003e now takes a config tuple\ninstead of individual arguments. Usages should be updated to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.service.DispatchServer(dispatcher_config)\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.service.WorkerServer\u003c/code\u003e now takes a config tuple\ninstead of individual arguments. Usages should be updated to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.service.WorkerServer(worker_config)\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRemoves \u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.Strategy.experimental_make_numpy_dataset\u003c/code\u003e. Please\nuse \u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.from_tensor_slices\u003c/code\u003e instead.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRenames \u003ccode\u003eexperimental_hints\u003c/code\u003e in\n\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.StrategyExtended.reduce_to\u003c/code\u003e,\n\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.StrategyExtended.batch_reduce_to\u003c/code\u003e,\n\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.ReplicaContext.all_reduce\u003c/code\u003e to \u003ccode\u003eoptions\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRenames \u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.experimental.CollectiveHints\u003c/code\u003e to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.experimental.CommunicationOptions\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRenames \u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.experimental.CollectiveCommunication\u003c/code\u003e to\n\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.experimental.CommunicationImplementation\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRenames\n\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.Strategy.experimental_distribute_datasets_from_function\u003c/code\u003e\nto \u003ccode\u003edistribute_datasets_from_function\u003c/code\u003e as it is no longer experimental.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRemoves \u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.Strategy.experimental_run_v2\u003c/code\u003e method, which was\ndeprecated in TF 2.2.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.lite\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.quantization.quantize_and_dequantize_v2\u003c/code\u003e has been introduced, which\nupdates the gradient definition for quantization which is outside the\nrange to be 0. To simulate the V1 the behavior of\n\u003ccode\u003etf.quantization.quantize_and_dequantize(...)\u003c/code\u003e use\n\u003ccode\u003etf.grad_pass_through(tf.quantization.quantize_and_dequantize_v2)(...)\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eBuilding TensorFlow:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWindows platform builds: TensorFlow on Windows under MSVC is now built\nwith \u003ccode\u003e--copt=/experimental:preprocessor --host_copt=/experimental:preprocessor\u003c/code\u003e (see \u003ccode\u003e.bazelrc\u003c/code\u003e for more\ndetails). Builds including TensorFlow may fail with unexpected syntax\nerrors if these flags are absent. See also\n\u003ca href=\"https://groups.google.com/a/tensorflow.org/g/build/c/LbAw8RILvTg/m/ttnuhYU2BgAJ\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ethis thread on SIG Build\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-known-caveats-6\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" href=\"#known-caveats-6\"\u003eKnown Caveats\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision\u003c/code\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhen using mixed precision, calling \u003ccode\u003eRMSprop.apply_gradients\u003c/code\u003e or\n\u003ccode\u003eNadam.apply_gradients\u003c/code\u003e outside a \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e does not work and will\nraise the AttributeError \"Tensor.op is meaningless when eager execution\nis enabled\". 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIntroduces experimental support for a new module named\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/experimental/numpy\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.experimental.numpy\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e,\nwhich is a NumPy-compatible API for writing TF programs. This module\nprovides class \u003ccode\u003endarray\u003c/code\u003e, which mimics the \u003ccode\u003endarray\u003c/code\u003e class in NumPy, and\nwraps an immutable \u003ccode\u003etf.Tensor\u003c/code\u003e under the hood. A subset of NumPy functions\n(e.g. \u003ccode\u003enumpy.add\u003c/code\u003e) are provided. Their inter-operation with TF facilities is\nseamless in most cases. See\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/python/ops/numpy_ops/README.md\"\u003etensorflow/python/ops/numpy_ops/README.md\u003c/a\u003e\nfor details of what operations are supported and what are the differences\nfrom NumPy.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.types.experimental.TensorLike\u003c/code\u003e is a new \u003ccode\u003eUnion\u003c/code\u003e type that can be used as\ntype annotation for variables representing a Tensor or a value that can be\nconverted to Tensor by \u003ccode\u003etf.convert_to_tensor\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCalling ops with a python constants or numpy values is now consistent with\ntf.convert_to_tensor behavior. This avoids operations like tf.reshape\ntruncating inputs such as from int64 to int32.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdds \u003ccode\u003etf.sparse.map_values\u003c/code\u003e to apply a function to the \u003ccode\u003e.value\u003c/code\u003es of\n\u003ccode\u003eSparseTensor\u003c/code\u003e arguments.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe Python bitwise operators for \u003ccode\u003eTensor\u003c/code\u003e (\u003ccode\u003e__and__\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003e__or__\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003e__xor__\u003c/code\u003e\nand \u003ccode\u003e__invert__\u003c/code\u003e now support non-\u003ccode\u003ebool\u003c/code\u003e arguments and apply the\ncorresponding bitwise ops. \u003ccode\u003ebool\u003c/code\u003e arguments continue to be supported and\ndispatch to logical ops. This brings them more in line with Python and NumPy\nbehavior.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdds \u003ccode\u003etf.SparseTensor.with_values\u003c/code\u003e. This returns a new SparseTensor with the\nsame sparsity pattern, but with new provided values. It is similar to the\n\u003ccode\u003ewith_values\u003c/code\u003e function of \u003ccode\u003eRaggedTensor\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdds \u003ccode\u003eStatelessCase\u003c/code\u003e op, and uses it if none of case branches has stateful\nops.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdds \u003ccode\u003etf.config.experimental.get_memory_usage\u003c/code\u003e to return total memory usage\nof the device.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdds gradients for \u003ccode\u003eRaggedTensorToVariant\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eRaggedTensorFromVariant\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eImprove shape inference of nested function calls by supporting constant\nfolding across Arg nodes which makes more static values available to shape\ninference functions.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.debugging\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.debugging.assert_shapes()\u003c/code\u003e now works on \u003ccode\u003eSparseTensor\u003c/code\u003es (Fixes\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/36268\" data-hovercard-type=\"issue\" data-hovercard-url=\"/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/36268/hovercard\"\u003e#36268\u003c/a\u003e).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGPU\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdds Support for\n\u003ca href=\"https://blogs.nvidia.com/blog/2020/05/14/tensorfloat-32-precision-format/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eTensorFloat-32\u003c/a\u003e\non Ampere based GPUs.TensorFloat-32, or TF32 for short, is a math mode\nfor NVIDIA Ampere based GPUs which causes certain float32 ops, such as\nmatrix multiplications and convolutions, to run much faster on Ampere\nGPUs but with reduced precision. This reduced precision has not been\nfound to effect convergence quality of deep learning models in practice.\nTensorFloat-32 is enabled by default, but can be disabled with\n\u003ccode\u003etf.config.experimental.enable_tensor_float_32_execution\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.math\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdds \u003ccode\u003etf.math.erfcinv\u003c/code\u003e, the inverse to \u003ccode\u003etf.math.erfc\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.nn\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.nn.max_pool2d\u003c/code\u003e now supports explicit padding.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.image\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdds deterministic \u003ccode\u003etf.image.stateless_random_*\u003c/code\u003e functions for each\n\u003ccode\u003etf.image.random_*\u003c/code\u003e function. Added a new op\n\u003ccode\u003estateless_sample_distorted_bounding_box\u003c/code\u003e which is a deterministic\nversion of \u003ccode\u003esample_distorted_bounding_box\u003c/code\u003e op. Given the same seed,\nthese stateless functions/ops produce the same results independent of\nhow many times the function is called, and independent of global seed\nsettings.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdds deterministic \u003ccode\u003etf.image.resize\u003c/code\u003e backprop CUDA kernels for\n\u003ccode\u003emethod=ResizeMethod.BILINEAR\u003c/code\u003e (the default method). Enable by setting\nthe environment variable \u003ccode\u003eTF_DETERMINISTIC_OPS\u003c/code\u003e to \u003ccode\u003e\"true\"\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003e\"1\"\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.print\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBug fix in \u003ccode\u003etf.print()\u003c/code\u003e with \u003ccode\u003eOrderedDict\u003c/code\u003e where if an \u003ccode\u003eOrderedDict\u003c/code\u003e\ndidn't have the keys sorted, the keys and values were not being printed\nin accordance with their correct mapping.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.train.Checkpoint\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNow accepts a \u003ccode\u003eroot\u003c/code\u003e argument in the initialization, which generates a\ncheckpoint with a root object. This allows users to create a\n\u003ccode\u003eCheckpoint\u003c/code\u003e object that is compatible with Keras \u003ccode\u003emodel.save_weights()\u003c/code\u003e\nand \u003ccode\u003emodel.load_weights\u003c/code\u003e. The checkpoint is also compatible with the\ncheckpoint saved in the \u003ccode\u003evariables/\u003c/code\u003e folder in the SavedModel.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhen restoring, \u003ccode\u003esave_path\u003c/code\u003e can be a path to a SavedModel. The function\nwill automatically find the checkpoint in the SavedModel.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-tfdata\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" href=\"#tfdata\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e:\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdds new \u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.service.register_dataset\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.service.from_dataset_id\u003c/code\u003e APIs to enable one process to\nregister a dataset with the tf.data service, and another process to consume\ndata from the dataset.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdds support for dispatcher fault tolerance. To enable fault tolerance,\nconfigure a \u003ccode\u003ework_dir\u003c/code\u003e when running your dispatcher server and set\n\u003ccode\u003edispatcher_fault_tolerance=True\u003c/code\u003e. The dispatcher will store its state to\n\u003ccode\u003ework_dir\u003c/code\u003e, so that on restart it can continue from its previous state after\nrestart.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdds support for sharing dataset graphs via shared filesystem instead of\nover RPC. This reduces load on the dispatcher, improving performance of\ndistributing datasets. For this to work, the dispatcher's \u003ccode\u003ework_dir\u003c/code\u003e must be\naccessible from workers. If the worker fails to read from the \u003ccode\u003ework_dir\u003c/code\u003e, it\nfalls back to using RPC for dataset graph transfer.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdds support for a new \"distributed_epoch\" processing mode. This processing\nmode distributes a dataset across all tf.data workers, instead of having\neach worker process the full dataset. See\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/data/experimental/service#understand_processing_mode\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ethe tf.data service docs\u003c/a\u003e\nto learn more.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdds optional \u003ccode\u003eexclude_cols\u003c/code\u003e parameter to CsvDataset. This parameter is the\ncomplement of \u003ccode\u003eselect_cols\u003c/code\u003e; at most one of these should be specified.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWe have implemented an optimization which reorders data-discarding\ntransformations such as \u003ccode\u003etake\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eshard\u003c/code\u003e to happen earlier in the dataset\nwhen it is safe to do so. The optimization can be disabled via the\n\u003ccode\u003eexperimental_optimization.reorder_data_discarding_ops\u003c/code\u003e dataset option.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Options\u003c/code\u003e were previously immutable and can now be overridden.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data.Dataset.from_generator\u003c/code\u003e now supports Ragged and Sparse tensors with\na new \u003ccode\u003eoutput_signature\u003c/code\u003e argument, which allows \u003ccode\u003efrom_generator\u003c/code\u003e to produce\nany type describable by a \u003ccode\u003etf.TypeSpec\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data.experimental.AUTOTUNE\u003c/code\u003e is now available in the core API as\n\u003ccode\u003etf.data.AUTOTUNE\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-tfdistribute\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" via\n\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.experimental.ParameterServerStrategy\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eReplaces the existing\n\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.experimental.ParameterServerStrategy\u003c/code\u003e symbol with a new\nclass that is for parameter server training in TF2. Usage of the old\nsymbol, usually with Estimator API, should be \u003cstrong\u003ereplaced\u003c/strong\u003e with\n[\u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v1.distribute.experimental.ParameterServerStrategy\u003c/code\u003e].\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded \u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.experimental.coordinator.*\u003c/code\u003e namespace, including\nthe main API \u003ccode\u003eClusterCoordinator\u003c/code\u003e for coordinating the training cluster,\nthe related data structure \u003ccode\u003eRemoteValue\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003ePerWorkerValue\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eMultiWorkerMirroredStrategy\u003c/code\u003e](\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/distribute/MultiWorkerMirroredStrategy\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ehttps://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/distribute/MultiWorkerMirroredStrategy\u003c/a\u003e)\nis now a stable API and is no longer considered experimental. Some of the\nmajor improvements involve handling peer failure and many bug fixes. Please\ncheck out the detailed tutorial on\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/tutorials/distribute/multi_worker_with_keras\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eMulti-worer training with Keras\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdds \u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.Strategy.gather\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.ReplicaContext.all_gather\u003c/code\u003e APIs to support gathering dense\ndistributed values.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFixes various issues with saving a distributed model.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFunctional model construction does not need to maintain a global\nworkspace graph, removing memory leaks especially when building many\nmodels or very large models.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFunctional model construction should be ~8-10% faster on average.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFunctional models can now contain non-symbolic values in their call\ninputs inside of the first positional argument.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSeveral classes of TF ops that were not reliably converted to Keras\nlayers during functional API construction should now work,\ne.g.\u003ccode\u003etf.image.ssim_multiscale\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eError messages when Functional API construction goes wrong (and when ops\ncannot be converted to Keras layers automatically) should be clearer and\neasier to understand.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eOptimizer.minimize\u003c/code\u003e can now accept a loss \u003ccode\u003eTensor\u003c/code\u003e and a \u003ccode\u003eGradientTape\u003c/code\u003e as\nan alternative to accepting a \u003ccode\u003ecallable\u003c/code\u003e loss.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdds \u003ccode\u003ebeta\u003c/code\u003e hyperparameter to\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/keras/optimizers/Ftrl\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eFTRL\u003c/a\u003e\noptimizer classes (Keras and others) to match\n\u003ca href=\"https://research.google.com/pubs/archive/41159.pdf\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eFTRL paper\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eOptimizer.__init__\u003c/code\u003e now accepts a \u003ccode\u003egradient_aggregator\u003c/code\u003e to allow for\ncustomization of how gradients are aggregated across devices, as well as\n\u003ccode\u003egradients_transformers\u003c/code\u003e to allow for custom gradient transformations (such\nas gradient clipping).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eImprovements to Keras preprocessing layers:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTextVectorization can now accept a vocabulary list or file as an init\narg.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNormalization can now accept mean and variance values as init args.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIn \u003ccode\u003eAttention\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eAdditiveAttention\u003c/code\u003e layers, the \u003ccode\u003ecall()\u003c/code\u003e method now\naccepts a \u003ccode\u003ereturn_attention_scores\u003c/code\u003e argument. When set to True, the layer\nreturns the attention scores as an additional output argument.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdds \u003ccode\u003etf.metrics.log_cosh\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003etf.metrics.logcosh\u003c/code\u003e API entrypoints with the\nsame implementation as their \u003ccode\u003etf.losses\u003c/code\u003e equivalent.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFor Keras model, the individual call of \u003ccode\u003eModel.evaluate\u003c/code\u003e uses no cached data\nfor evaluation, while \u003ccode\u003eModel.fit\u003c/code\u003e uses cached data when \u003ccode\u003evalidation_data\u003c/code\u003e\narg is provided for better performance.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdds a \u003ccode\u003esave_traces\u003c/code\u003e argument to \u003ccode\u003emodel.save\u003c/code\u003e/ \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.models.save_model\u003c/code\u003e\nwhich determines whether the SavedModel format stores the Keras model/layer\ncall functions. The traced functions allow Keras to revive custom models and\nlayers without the original class definition, but if this isn't required the\ntracing can be disabled with the added option.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe \u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision\u003c/code\u003e API is now non-experimental. The\nnon-experimental API differs from the experimental API in several ways.\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision.Policy\u003c/code\u003e no longer takes in a\n\u003ccode\u003etf.mixed_precision. experimental.LossScale\u003c/code\u003e in the constructor, and no\nlonger has a \u003ccode\u003eLossScale\u003c/code\u003e associated with it. Instead, \u003ccode\u003eModel.compile\u003c/code\u003e\nwill automatically wrap the optimizer with a \u003ccode\u003eLossScaleOptimizer\u003c/code\u003e using\ndynamic loss scaling if \u003ccode\u003ePolicy.name\u003c/code\u003e is \"mixed_float16\".\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision.LossScaleOptimizer\u003c/code\u003e's constructor takes in\ndifferent arguments. In particular, it no longer takes in a \u003ccode\u003eLossScale\u003c/code\u003e,\nand there is no longer a \u003ccode\u003eLossScale\u003c/code\u003e associated with the\n\u003ccode\u003eLossScaleOptimizer\u003c/code\u003e. Instead, \u003ccode\u003eLossScaleOptimizer\u003c/code\u003e directly implements\nfixed or dynamic loss scaling. See the documentation of\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/keras/mixed_precision/experimental/LossScaleOptimizer?version=nightly\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision.experimental.LossScaleOptimizer\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\nfor details on the differences between the experimental\n\u003ccode\u003eLossScaleOptimizer\u003c/code\u003e and the new non-experimental \u003ccode\u003eLossScaleOptimizer\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.mixed_precision.experimental.LossScale\u003c/code\u003e and its subclasses are\ndeprecated, as all of its functionality now exists within\n\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.mixed_precision.LossScaleOptimizer\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3 dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e adds two new mechanisms to solve input pipeline bottlenecks and\nsave resources:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/data/experimental/snapshot\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003esnapshot\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/data/experimental/service\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003etf.data service\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn addition checkout the detailed\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/guide/data_performance_analysis\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eguide\u003c/a\u003e for\nanalyzing input pipeline performance with TF Profiler.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/distribute/TPUStrategy\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.TPUStrategy\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\nis now a stable API and no longer considered experimental for TensorFlow.\n(earlier \u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.experimental.TPUStrategy\u003c/code\u003e).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/guide/profiler\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eTF Profiler\u003c/a\u003e introduces two new\ntools: a memory profiler to visualize your model’s memory usage over time\nand a \u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/guide/profiler#events\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003epython tracer\u003c/a\u003e\nwhich allows you to trace python function calls in your model. Usability\nimprovements include better diagnostic messages and\n\u003ca href=\"https://tensorflow.org/guide/profiler#collect_performance_data\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eprofile options\u003c/a\u003e\nto customize the host and device trace verbosity level.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIntroduces experimental support for Keras Preprocessing Layers API\n(\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/keras/layers/experimental/preprocessing?version=nightly\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras.layers.experimental.preprocessing.*\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e)\nto handle data preprocessing operations, with support for composite tensor\ninputs. Please see below for additional details on these layers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTFLite now properly supports dynamic shapes during conversion and inference.\nWe’ve also added opt-in support on Android and iOS for\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/tree/master/tensorflow/lite/delegates/xnnpack\"\u003eXNNPACK\u003c/a\u003e,\na highly optimized set of CPU kernels, as well as opt-in support for\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/lite/g3doc/performance/gpu_advanced.md#running-quantized-models-experimental\"\u003eexecuting quantized models on the GPU\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eLibtensorflow packages are available in GCS starting this release. We have\nalso started to\n\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow#official-builds\"\u003erelease a nightly version of these packages\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe experimental Python API\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/debugging/experimental/enable_dump_debug_info\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.debugging.experimental.enable_dump_debug_info()\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\nnow allows you to instrument a TensorFlow program and dump debugging\ninformation to a directory on the file system. The directory can be read and\nvisualized by a new interactive dashboard in TensorBoard 2.3 called\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/tensorboard/debugger_v2\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eDebugger V2\u003c/a\u003e, which\nreveals the details of the TensorFlow program including graph structures,\nhistory of op executions at the Python (eager) and intra-graph levels, the\nruntime dtype, shape, and numerical composition of tensors, as well as their\ncode locations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-breaking-changes-16\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" href=\"#breaking-changes-16\"\u003eBreaking Changes\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIncreases the \u003cstrong\u003eminimum bazel version\u003c/strong\u003e required to build TF to \u003cstrong\u003e3.1.0\u003c/strong\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMakes the following (breaking) changes to the \u003ccode\u003etf.data\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eC++ API: - \u003ccode\u003eIteratorBase::RestoreInternal\u003c/code\u003e,\n\u003ccode\u003eIteratorBase::SaveInternal\u003c/code\u003e, and \u003ccode\u003eDatasetBase::CheckExternalState\u003c/code\u003e\nbecome pure-virtual and subclasses are now expected to provide an\nimplementation.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe deprecated \u003ccode\u003eDatasetBase::IsStateful\u003c/code\u003e method is removed in favor of\n\u003ccode\u003eDatasetBase::CheckExternalState\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDeprecated overrides of \u003ccode\u003eDatasetBase::MakeIterator\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003eMakeIteratorFromInputElement\u003c/code\u003e are removed.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe signature of \u003ccode\u003etensorflow::data::IteratorBase::SaveInternal\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003etensorflow::data::IteratorBase::SaveInput\u003c/code\u003e has been extended with\n\u003ccode\u003eSerializationContext\u003c/code\u003e argument to enable overriding the default policy\nfor the handling external state during iterator checkpointing. This is\nnot a backwards compatible change and all subclasses of \u003ccode\u003eIteratorBase\u003c/code\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eneed to be updated\u003c/em\u003e accordingly.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.keras\u003c/code\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd a new \u003ccode\u003eBackupAndRestore\u003c/code\u003e callback for handling distributed training\nfailures \u0026amp; restarts. Please take a look at this\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/tutorials/distribute/multi_worker_with_keras\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003etutorial\u003c/a\u003e\nfor details on how to use the callback.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.image.extract_glimpse\u003c/code\u003e has been updated to correctly process the case\nwhere \u003ccode\u003ecentered=False\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003enormalized=False\u003c/code\u003e. This is a breaking change as\nthe output is different from (incorrect) previous versions. Note this\nbreaking change only impacts \u003ccode\u003etf.image.extract_glimpse\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v2.image.extract_glimpse\u003c/code\u003e API endpoints. The behavior of\n\u003ccode\u003etf.compat.v1.image.extract_glimpse\u003c/code\u003e does not change. The behavior of\nexisting C++ kernel \u003ccode\u003eExtractGlimpse\u003c/code\u003e does not change either, so saved models\nusing \u003ccode\u003etf.raw_ops.ExtractGlimpse\u003c/code\u003e will not be impacted.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-known-caveats-7\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca class=\"heading-link\" href=\"#known-caveats-7\"\u003eKnown function\u003c/code\u003e to dynamically choose the\nimplementation based on underlying device placement.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEager:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd \u003ccode\u003ereduce_logsumexp\u003c/code\u003e benchmark with experiment compile.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGive \u003ccode\u003eEagerTensor\u003c/code\u003es a meaningful \u003ccode\u003e__array__\u003c/code\u003e implementation.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd another version of defun matmul for performance analysis.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e/AutoGraph:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eAutoGraph\u003c/code\u003e now includes into TensorFlow loops any variables that are\nclosed over by local functions. Previously, such variables were\nsometimes incorrectly ignored.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003efunctions returned by the \u003ccode\u003eget_concrete_function\u003c/code\u003e method of\n\u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e objects can now be called with arguments consistent with\nthe original arguments or type specs passed to \u003ccode\u003eget_concrete_function\u003c/code\u003e.\nThis calling convention is now the preferred way to use concrete\nfunctions with nested values and composite tensors. Please check the\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/guide/concrete_function\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eguide\u003c/a\u003e for more\ndetails on \u003ccode\u003econcrete_ function\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUpdate \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e's \u003ccode\u003eexperimental_relax_shapes\u003c/code\u003e to handle composite\ntensors appropriately.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOptimize \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e invocation, by removing redundant list converter.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e will retrace when called with a different variable instead\nof simply using the \u003ccode\u003edtype\u003c/code\u003e \u0026amp; \u003ccode\u003eshape\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/33862\" data-hovercard-type=\"issue\" data-hovercard-url=\"/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/33862/hovercard\"\u003eImprove support\u003c/a\u003e\nfor dynamically-sized TensorArray inside \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.math\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNarrow down \u003ccode\u003eargmin\u003c/code\u003e/\u003ccode\u003eargmax\u003c/code\u003e contract to always return the smallest\nindex for ties.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.math.reduce_variance\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003etf.math.reduce_std\u003c/code\u003e return correct\ncomputation for complex types and no longer support integer types.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd Bessel functions of order 0,1 to \u003ccode\u003etf.math.special\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.divide\u003c/code\u003e now always returns a tensor to be consistent with\ndocumentation and other APIs.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.image\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eReplaced\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/versions/r2.3/api_docs/python/tf/image/non_max_suppression_padded?hl=en\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.image.non_max_suppression_padded\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\nwith a new implementation that supports batched inputs, which is\nconsiderably faster on TPUs and GPUs. Boxes with area=0 will be ignored.\nExisting usage with single inputs should still work as before.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.linalg\u003c/code\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd \u003ccode\u003etf.linalg.banded_triangular_solve\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.random\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd \u003ccode\u003etf.random.stateless_parameterized_truncated_normal\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.ragged\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul operations.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.RaggedTensor\u003c/code\u003e:\n\u003cul loading\nmodels and weights.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUpdate \u003ccode\u003etf.saved_model.SaveOptions\u003c/code\u003e with\n\u003ca with default value \u003ccode\u003eNone\u003c/code\u003e to choose the I/O device for saving\nmodels and weights.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMutable tables now restore checkpointed values when rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.DistributedIterator\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\nto distribute input data when using \u003ccode\u003etf.distribute\u003c/code\u003e to scale training on\nmultiple devices.\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdded a\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/versions/r2.3/api_docs/python/tf/distribute/DistributedIterator?hl=en#get_next_as_optional\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eget_next_as_optional\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\nmethod for\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/versions/r2.3/api_docs/python/tf/distribute/DistributedIterator?hl=en\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.DistributedIterator\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\nclass to return a \u003ccode\u003etf.experimental.Optional\u003c/code\u003e instance that contains the\nnext value for all replicas or none instead of raising an out of range\nerror. Also see \u003cem\u003enew\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/tutorials/distribute/input\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eguide on input distribution\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAllow var.assign on MirroredVariables with aggregation=NONE in replica\ncontext. Previously this would raise an error. We now allow this because\nmany users and library writers find using \u003ccode\u003e.assign\u003c/code\u003e in replica context to be\nmore convenient, instead of having to use \u003ccode\u003eStrategy.extended.update\u003c/code\u003e which\nwas the previous way of updating variables in this situation.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.experimental.MultiWorkerMirroredStrategy\u003c/code\u003e adds support for\npartial batches. Workers running out of data now continue to participate in\nthe training with empty inputs, instead of raising an error. Learn more\nabout\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.tensorflow.org/tutorials/distribute/input#partial_batches\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003epartial batches here\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eImprove the performance of reading metrics eagerly under\n\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.experimental.MultiWorkerMirroredStrategy\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFix the issue that \u003ccode\u003estrategy.reduce()\u003c/code\u003e inside \u003ccode\u003etf.function\u003c/code\u003e may raise\nexceptions when the values to reduce are from loops or if-clauses.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFix the issue that \u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.MirroredStrategy\u003c/code\u003e cannot be used together\nwith \u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.experimental.MultiWorkerMirroredStrategy\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd a \u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.cluster_resolver.TPUClusterResolver.connect\u003c/code\u003e API to\nsimplify TPU initialization.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd \u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.Strategy.gather\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.ReplicaContext.all_gather\u003c/code\u003e methods to gather and concatenate\n\u003ccode\u003etf.distribute.DistributedValues\u003c/code\u003e across workers and devices.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"user-content-tfkeras-1\"
